title: opening pubs but not schools doesnt add up
story: PRAISE the Lord – the decision is made. You can now at last be within ft in of someone outside your immediate household! What’s more, from July , you will be able to eat in restaurants, have a drink and, of course, continue shopping.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhat you won’t be able to do, unless you are very fortunate, is to get your children into school, which says something about our national priorities. Make no mistake about it, this is a “national emergency”. Education should have the upfront priority that we rightly give the NHS and saving our economy. The failure since the beginning of March to plan ahead for getting all schools and all youngsters back into the classroom has been reprehensible.I say all schools because the majority have been open for the children of key workers and for children designated as vulnerable.Many teachers have been doing a first-class job trying to keep in touch with children at home, providing them with online tuition, homework and marking. But there is still time to mobilise all the necessary resources to make it possible to get children back to school for at least a couple of weeks before the end of this term.Yes, it would involve finding extra premises for schools with inadequate space. Yes, we would have to appeal to teachers who have recently retired to come back for perhaps a few hours a week. Yes, we would need to employ supply teachers.In addition we could use university students, who won’t be finding summer jobs any time soon, to assist.Of course, we don’t have that reliable summer weather that will allow teaching outside on a regular basis, butDenmark can place many lessons in an outside setting, we can.If the French, Lord help us, can get their schools mobilised and back to full operation, we can. Their trade unions are far more bolshy than ours, and teachers regrettably much less well paid.So we need a combination of creativity, imagination and drive to get pupils back. We need to rebuild the confidence of parents and staff that they are highly unlikely to contract the virus from the children, or of the children passing it on to each other.That way, we can have ironed out the glitches and be ready in September to be absolutely on the ball. Small group tutoring for recovery programmes, mentoring not just organised centrally, but co-ordinated locally.For anyone who doesn’t believe that two or three weeks matter in terms of education, when children have been out of school since the middle of March, then think again. This is about equality, narrowing the gap between the haves and have-nots, and opening a window on the world. But it is also more than that. It’s a place of social interaction, of well-being and of safety. Don’t take my word for it. Take the word of the Royal College of Paediatricians, the people whose whole le is spent on the well-being of children. They are very clear: Schools must , children need each other as well as their teachers.The recognition of the importance of schools was something I was proud to oversee in , when the incoming government’s priority slogan was, “education, education, education”.Don’t get me wrong. The belated announcement last week of a one per cent uplt for all schools and a £million pot for an online recovery programme is extremely welcome. A pity, therefore, that in making a really great announcement, the Government managed not to put any money aside for the  to -year-olds in further education, who are surely the target group we would want to be helping the most.So, thank you to all those who have done everything they can to keep the wheels on the cart over the past dficult three and a half months. But now we need both national leadership and local organisation. To use an old adage, we need to think national but we need to act local. Education trusts, local authorities, teachers’ unions and all those committed to the future of this nation should want to come together to make it work.In the next ten days, while the Government thinks about its advice, others can get on with the job. Take what is working best and spread it.What can work in France or Denmark or Germany can certainly work here. We are not out of the woods yet, but we can take logical, rational and brave decisions. That is what leadership is all about.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry shaped hole happy royal family
story: To the rest of us, it’s a charming exception to the more formal royal photos of old.But how was it received by the person who’s so obviously missing from this image of paternal closeness . . .  Prince Harry Since a spokesman confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex would be inactive on their @sussexroyal Instagram account from Aprilthere’s no way of knowing whether Harry would have publicly thanked his father last Sunday or , indeed, he has done so in private.But given that he’s reportedly homesick for the UK, this photo — taken in December — must have prompted a visceral longing for home. How could it not The sense of countryside and fresh air it evokes, the tweed caps, the fingerless mittens, the ornate walking stick . . .  just the innate Britishness of it all. Such a far cry from the smog, red carpets, bling and supercars of LA.And then, of course, it’s a reminder of the people he’s known since birth.Those who, unlike the “mwah mwah”, showbiz crowd, love him for who, rather than what, he is.Whichever way you view his behaviour of late, it’s undeniable that there is a huge, Harry-shaped hole in this image of family togetherness.Of course, there are Zoom meetings to be had and, post-lockdown, the occasional visit to be made. But it’s never quite the same.And therein lies the rub when you marry someone from another country.At first your initial attraction and then love for each other transcends geographical or cultural dferences.But when children come along and you’re required to stay in one place, inevitably one of you has to give up more than the other.Meghan tried it, albeit for a very short time, and now Harry is the one living thousands of miles away from his family and the only le he’s ever known.He made the decision to step down as a senior royal and decamp to the US for the sake of his new family — Meghan and Archie — but that doesn’t make it any less tough to see the old one ticking over nicely without him.A couple of years ago, I was in a central London restaurant with a group of other married couples and, much to the annoyance of we wives, the husbands couldn’t take their eyes off a woman sitting at the bar.Wearing the shortest of dresses, her legs were encircled around the object of her affections and her tongue made frequent visits to his ear.I recognised the man as actor Stephen Campbell Moore, ex-husband of The Crown star Claire Foy, and his obviously smitten companion as Sophie Cookson, who played Christine Keeler in last year’s BBC drama about the Profumo scandal.Fast forward to lockdown and this photo, suggests the couple may now be expecting their first child.The fond arrival of which will mean a heavy-hearted goodbye to those late-night, lust-filled liaisons that had the rest of us drooling with envy.Kaiser Chiefs frontman Ricky Wilson says he amuses himself by lying in interviews then changing his Wikipedia page to match his inventions.It reminds me of my stint as a royal correspondent when, after days of being on the road together, we would challenge each other to use silly names in stories.Hence, “Toby Lerone” was quoted in an article filed from the royals’ favourite ski resort in Switzerland, and in another story to do with Italy, “Sam Buca” made an appearance.Daft, I know, but it amused usno one .Mr Pendragon, who refuses to pay to park, says they stopped him from leaving his car on nearby roads.Shouldn’t he have been on horseback Bored by St Tropez, billionaires are reportedly snapping up “expedition yachts” that will take them to more adventurous corners of the globe.The one owned by US billionaire Ray Dalio has three deep-ing submersibles, and converted former Soviet spy boat Olivia is currently on the market for £million.Back home, lock-down quarantine rules have forced a  per cent rise in multi-millionaire Brits splashing their cash on vast private pools.Meanwhile, the rest of us will make do with a boat in the bath and a paddling pool.Sarah Ferguson – aka Prince Andrew’s ex we – is building up quite a following on her YouTube channel, where she reads children’s books such as The Wonky Donkey and Little Red Riding Hood while wearing fancy dress.Her success is no surprise, because on the many occasions I’ve seen her at charity events, she always connects brilliantly with the children in attendance.But personally, I can’t wait for her to get round to the critically acclaimed Idan Hadari book about a boy who wants to be famous.It’s called Andrew’s Claim To Fame.Or, in the Duke of York’s case, should that be infamy Yep. She now looks about .When -year-old Khairi Saadallah started his alleged kne rampage in a Reading park, a young, off-duty police officer ran towards the danger and rugby tackled him to the ground.It was a selfless act of bravery that, according to sources, saved “many more people dying”.Meanwhile, a judge has praised the bravery of PC Andrew Harper, who died after being dragged along by a car as he chased some thieves.Both of these are salutary reminders that, while every police force in the world has a few bad apples, the majority of those working in law enforcement are undeniably courageous people doing a tough job that most of us would shy away from.The latest money-making exercise candle from Gwyneth Paltrow is called This Smells Like My Orgasm.Which, as you ask, is “tart grapefruit, neroli, and ripe cassis berries blended with gunpowder tea and Turkish rose absolutes”. Er, right.Like its highly successful predecessor This Smells Like My Vagina candle – which, for the blissfully unaware, is “geranium, citrusy bergamot, and cedar absolutes juxtaposed with Damask rose and ambrette seed” – it costs£.Clearly, she’s a sales genius who could flog underwear to a nudist, but one suspects any attempt to branch out with a, to put it politely, Smells Like My Winkle range might prove a tougher sell.Hmmm. While the new name — Lost The Pot Noodle — is inspired, one notes that it now requires the consumer to put the ingredients in a mug or make it in a pan on the stove.As any self-respecting, Olympically idle student will tell you, a clean mug is a rarer sighting than an eclipse and, as for a pan, eventhey own one it will be housing enough penicillin growth to solve America’s recent shortage.So, memo to Unilever: Don’t phase out the original just yet.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new study reveals eight in ten brits feel they settled for their partner
story: A study of , adults found a ‘guess that will do’ approach has been adopted because they either haven’t been able to afford better, or get what they really want. Incredibly,  per cent of adults have found themselves in a relationship with someone they didn’t think was ‘the one’ – with  per cent doing so because they didn’t want to be left on the shelf and  per cent worrying they’d never find love.And seven in ten adults have at some point accepted a salary which was far from ideal, with a fth feeling there wasn’t room for negotiation and one quarter hoping a pay rise might happen in the future.Of those polled,  per cent have also accepted a job they didn’t want, largely because they couldn’t find anything better.A spokeswoman for Lottoland, which carried out the research in connection with their new Lotto Plus Multiple Millionaires Bonus draw, said: “We know that people often want more out of le, and as such strive to do better, but the findings do indicate an acceptance that things can’t always be perfect.“However, there should be some areas of le where you don’t settle for second best.It is human nature to want more – more fun, more spontaneity, and more choice – and that’s why we’re introducing more choice and more opportunities for our own customers.”The study also found a house, friendships, and a car are among the other le changing things adults have settled for, when they really didn’t want to.Almost two third of adults have ended up moving into a house which wasn’t their dream home, with money the chief factor.And  per cent have found themselves in unhealthy friendships, with confidence cited as the main reason for not pursuing alternative relationships.But when it comes to settling in le, not all decisions are le changing.Nearly four in  adults have had to settle on a supermarket’s own brand of food over something posher, while  per cent have made do with a cheap restaurant rather than opting for fine dining.Choosing a slice of cake smaller than one would like, and deciding on the house wine over something a little more refined also feature in the top  list.Furniture for the home, haircuts, shoes and gts are also among the things Brits have chosen, despite wanting better.It also emerged three in  have settled for the price of something rather than negotiating, and  per cent have resigned themselves to working long hours instead of meeting up with friends.. Salary. Job. Dream house. Car. Friendships. Partner. Supermarkets own food instead of branded. A cheaper restaurant over fine dining. Staying at home for the evening instead of going out with. Clothing brands. The price of something rather than negotiating. A gt for someone. Mobile phone   smart phone. Area you live in. House wine instead of the higher cost option. A self-catered holiday over a luxurious all inclusive. Furniture. Haircut. Shoes. Working longer hours instead of spending time with friends. Having a small slice of cake instead of a massive one. Clothes a size larger than youd like to be buying. Coffee - getting instant instead of the good stuff. TV. Decor. The cost of utility bills. Cheap beers. Who to socialise with. Handbags. Fitness gear Holidays, the area to live in, smart phones, and coffee also feature in the list as those things where sometimes, second best will have to do.But researchers from OnePoll found two thirds of those polled DO want more out of le, and the same percentage say the older they get, the less likely they are to settle for anything less than perfect.Four in  adults will only settle on somethingthey really don’t have a choice, and  per cent said money is always the decisive factor.Being too relaxed, lacking confidence, and wanting to go with the flow are also reasons why Brits don’t push to get what they want all the time.Butthey had the choice and felt able,  per cent would like to improve their financial situation, while  per cent want a better salary.One fth of adults would like to improve their relationships, and one third want to live somewhere nicer both in terms of house, and location.A spokeswoman for Lottoland added: “As a nation we’re go-getters, and striving to do better is part of who we are.Lottoland wants to mirror that by offering playing more chances to win, more flexibility and more enjoyment along the way.“In the spirit of offering more, we’re launching a special promotion for Lotto Plus players – the Multiple Millionaires Bonus Draw. title: gargling salt water solution reduce covid symptoms
story: Sea salt could boost the antiviral defence of cells that kicks in when you are affected by a cold, scientists at the University of Edinburgh said.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe new study builds on a trial published in , which found participants who gargled and cleared their nose with a saltwater solution had fewer coughs and less congestion.Its not yet been tested on those with SARS-CoV- - the virus which causes Covid-.Researchers are now recruiting adults to take part in trials to find out its effectiveness on the new bug, which has so far killed more than , people in the UK.Professor Aziz Sheikh, director of the universitys Usher Institute, said: We are now moving to trial our saltwater intervention in those with suspected or confirmed Covid-, and hope it will prove to be a useful measure to reduce the impact and spread of the infection.It only requires salt, water and some understanding of procedure so should -found to be effective - be easy and inexpensive to implement widely.Half of the participants in the original pilot study - known as the Edinburgh and Lothians Viral Intervention Study, or ELVIS - gargled saltwater while the other dealt with a cold as they normally would.Those joining the new trial will be asked to follow government advice on hygiene and self-isolation with one group again asked to gargle and clear their nose with salt water.It comes after experts said gargling mouthwash could kill coronavirus and slash the risk of infection.Just  seconds of swirling has proven effective against similar viruses, a review found.Ingredients in common mouthwashes damaged the bugs’ outer shell - making them harmless.Now experts have called for urgent research into the potential benefits of using the rinse to combat Covid-.They hope to establishpopular brands can inactivate the virus in the throat, where it is thought to multiply.Potentially useful ingredients include ethanol, povidone-iodine and cetylpyridinium.The findings are published in the journal Function.Hand washing and following the social distancing rules are still among the best ways to protect yourself from coronavirus, as well as staying healthy and using face coverings on public transport and in shops.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal navy first ever crewless boat pacific 24
story: More than £million has been spent on the Pacic  boat and other self-operated crafts.The boats could help operations including search-and-rescue and drug raids in the Caribbean and Middle East. Boats could be sent on inidual missions or in groups, reaching speeds of up to  knots . In pursuit mode, it has a range of  nautical miles. The Pacic  has been used in sea boat operations from Royal Navy warships for more than  years.But the new drone version of the boat could provide a more streamlined way of carrying out its wide range of operations - and even open up some new types of missions.The boats will be controlled from a parent ship, such as a frigate or destroyer.Defence Minister Jeremy Quin said: Commencing the trials of the crewless Pacic  boat is an important stepping stone in the Royal Navys development of its autonomous capability to ensure our fleet remains at the forefront of military innovation and technology, ready to meet the evolving threats of modern warfare.The crewless Pacic  is sponsored by NavyX, the specialist wing of the Royal Navy which trials cutting-edge technology for use on the front line.The team has worked in partnership with BAE Systems, which builds the Pacic  in Portsmouth, to commission the new boat.A prototype, controlled from the frigate HMS Argyll, debuted at the DSEI defence technology showcase in London last September, since when BAE and the Navy have pressed ahead with a working model fit for the front line.The vessels control system and sensors mean a sailor should be able to give the unmanned craft generic tasking, and the boat will decide for itself how it carries out that task.Lieutenant Commander Rob Manson of the NavyX team said: The autonomous nature of this craft adds huge capability and flexibility.Brooke Hoskins, Products and Training Services Director at BAE Systems said: We are proud to support the Royal Navys autonomous requirements, which includes increasing its operational effectiveness whilst reducing the burden on, or threat to, its sailors.Trials with the new craft begin this month, followed by trials with a Royal Navy warship later this year which should determine whether the UK invests in a fleet of such craft or just a few for specic missions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family 280k house raffle volvo pandemic
story: The winner will be given the keys to the house, which was built just two years ago and is worth around £, - and theyll also get a £, SUV thrown in too.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe house comes complete with a  sq ft garden and garage.Owner Dale Tate,  is also throwing in his own car - a x Volvo XC Hybrid - in a bid to woo would-be ticket-buyers.Dale lives at the property in Ossett, West Yorks, we Katherine and their four kids, but hasnt been able to sell his property during the pandemic.And he said he quickly became fed up with estate agents.“There’s only been one viewing in the past month, so I thought it wasn’t looking good, he said,“You’ve got to think outside the box with these things.”Competitors can buy as many of the , tickets as they want.The Tate family had hoped for a quick sale as they plan to move to Australia at the end of the year.Dale, who works as an engineer, said: People havent got anything to lose really - its only £.Your odds of winning the lottery are about  million to one, but this is , to oneyou spend £.“People spend more than that on a lottery ticket and have basically no chance of winning - but this is genuine.If all the tickets sell, then somebody has to win it.“It will make somebodys day, thats for sure.We will get the asking price for it, once the fees are taken out, including stamp duty and legal fees.Its not like were over-inflating the price and trying to make a huge profit on it.“Were not doing that at all.The family plan on relocating Down Under later in  to be closer to Katherine’s family.The home is listed with raffle site RaffallStelios Kounou, who owns the site, said: When I saw a spike in ticket sales, I looked to see why and saw that it was a family home.I recognised the users name as Id spoken to him before after he successfully sold thousands of pounds worth of tools through us and the winner only paid £.Ive seen a lot of house competitions in UK fail before because they dont sell enough tickets but whats good about this one is there is no ulterior motive.Because Dale is moving abroad, he has to sell him home.House raffles arent always a success - title: secret government ufo public senate intel unidentified data
story: The Committee requested the Pentagon release all data collected on unidentied aerial phenomenon and intrusions over restricted US airspace.The call for unidentied aerial phenomena review is a big win for those who seek more transparency on what the government knows about UFOs.“Assuming the report is properly prepared and delivered, there is no telling what the impacts could be, Christopher Mellon, a former top Pentagon intelligence official and Senate staffer who has pressed for more research on the topic, told Politico. Melon continued: That could range from revealing an unknown threat or military vulnerability to there have been probes visiting our planet, or anything in between.The  annual intelligence authorization bill, which still needs to be passed by the full Senate, was submitted by acting Intelligence Committee chairman Sen. Macro Rubio and others on June , . The submission raised concerns that the government has not devoted the appropriate amount of resources to UAP.The Committee remains concerned that there is no unied, comprehensive process within the federal government for collecting and analyzing intelligence on unidentied aerial phenomena, despite the potential threat, the committee states in its report on the bill.The bill orders the Director of National Intelligence to produce a thorough report with relevant agencies, including the FBI and the Office of Naval Intelligence. The unclassied report, which may include a classied annex, will contain details about a series of encounters with UAP and advanced aerial threats. Some of those encounters may not be with extraterrestrials, but instead adversaries of America testing the nations defenses.What’s more, the report must detail what information has been previously gathered on UAPs, how the data is collected and published, and what risks UFOs could pose.In April, the Pentagon declassied and released three videos taken by US Navy pilots showing mid-air encounters with what appeared to be UFOs.One of the videos was reportedly shot in November  and the other two in January . But exactly how much will be revealed in the new report depends on what the Pentagon deems unclassied.If the bill passes, the Pentagon will have  days to submit the report to Congress.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian oligarch 360m superyacht docks south of france
story: Andrey Melnichenko wowed onlookers as he pulled his enormous ft-long futuristic vessel with luxurious on-board pool and extravagant lounge decks into port. The impressive vessel, which comes complete with eight decks and masts that are almost ft tall, is the ninth largest yacht in the world and took four years to build.The luxury yacht features multiple dining rooms and several balconies which stylishly open up on the side of the hull.The yacht is powered by a hybrid diesel-electric package with controllable pitch propellers.Up to  lucky guests can be accommodated on the mega-boat, hosted by a crew of , according to reports.Aside from the opulent lounge, the superyacht boasts floor-to-ceiling windows, a combination of leather and wood furniture and a rotating bed.It also has free-floating spiral staircases and three masts that are taller than Big Ben and stretch up from the extraordinary wedge-shaped boat hull.One of the masts is accessible from the inside, but the crew dont need to climb them – the boat’s sails unfurl at the touch of a button.The masts are technical masterpieces, and can rotate to make the most of the wind when out at sea.The boat was also designed with bomb-proof glass windows and an owners cabin which is larger than most apartments in London or New York.The high-gloss ship is able to whir across the waves at speeds of up to .knots .The ship also boasts a garage fit for four vehicles and a submarine, as well as a helipad on the bow.Melnichenko named his superyacht A because in order for the vessel to be listed first in shipping registers.The total sail area is equal to that of half a football pitch, with two double-decker buses able to be hung from the masts.The Russian industrialists newest yacht also includes rotating masts that were built by Magma Strustures at Trafalgar Wharf, Portsmouth.The Russian billionaire is notorious for his extravagant lestyle.Alongside his two astonishing superyachts, the billionaire owns a customised Boeing  private jet, a villa in the French Riviera, a penthouse in New York and an estate near Ascot, England. He married his model we Aleksandra in an opulent ceremony in the South of France with singers Whitney Houston and Christina Aguilera leading the after-party.Melnichenko, , is also the father of a young daughter and has an estimated net worth of around £.billion, making him the th richest person in Russia and the th wealthiest person in the world.The Russian made his billions founding the fertiliser producer EuroChem, coal producer Suek, and power generator SGK. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry meghan 1m speech agency obamas
story: The couple have joined the same “world-leading” agency as their pal Serena Williams and the Obamas to help fund their new luxury lestyle.They will host discussions and give keynote speeches to trade associations, businesses and communities, the LA Times reported.Topics will include racial justice, gender equality, mental health and the environment — though reportedly not the Royal Family.PR expert Mark Borkowski claimed they could earn £million-plus each time.He said: “I’m surprised they haven’t done this sooner. It will be one of the great income generators for them. They will clean up — they are up there with the Obamas.“The speaker’s circuit is a natural safe space for them to plunder. And they are doing it in America, which is where the money is.”The couple need to earn millions to fund their lestyle in Los Angeles after quitting royal le.They are house-hunting while staying at Hollywood star Tyler Perry’s £million Beverly Hills mansion. They also need to pay for their own security — costing up to £million a year.They have signed up to the New York-based Harry Walker Agency, which bills itself as “the world’s leading speaker’s bureau”.Former US President Barack Obama reportedly earned £, for a  speech.Perry, , is also on the books. title: stay half in half out of lockdown well be happier
story: LOCKDOWN is pretty much over. The Prime Minister announced that we were at last allowed out of our Great British Hibernation.We can go to the pub, buy useless tat in shops and queue up for plaster lawn ornaments from garden centres. We can have the in-laws round to visit! Yoot!⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoris says that his decision was made on good scientic advice. Hmm, maybe. It is true that the infection rate for Covid has been dropping rapidly for some time. But it’s still there, still hanging around with mischief on its mind. All it takes is one person in a gathering of  or  at some pizza joint and that infection rate will be up again quickly enough.In some of the countries that have released their people from lockdown, a second spike has occurred.In Germany the famous “R” rate for infection is well above the dreaded one. South Korea and Spain have seen new outbreaks, too.But the truth is Boris didn’t have much of an option. The public is bored stf and the economy is wrecked.I suspect the decision was arrived at on those grounds, rather than strictly on the science. Everyone wants to go out and spend money. I am not sure why they do.  There were good things about lockdown — and it taught us one or two truths about ourselves.It was a pleasure to hear the birds singing, for example. A real delight to see the roads free from traffic. The skies are full of swts and swallows instead of the incessant airline flights. The quality of the air we breathe improved hugely as a result. So did the water quality of rivers and streams.We went out much, much less. As a consequence, many people saved an awful lot of money because they weren’t wasting it on buying rubbish from shops.People learned to cook — and ate home-prepared meals with their families. The truth is, in normal times, we eat out far more often than is good for us, financially or otherwise. And we shopped locally — the corner stores did a roaring trade — and less often, thus saving carbon emissions.Employers discovered that people could work from home perfectly well. Hopefully this will persuade some to scale back their offices and give people the chance to work from home.Imagine how many homes could be created from disused offices! We wouldn’t have to pave over half the country to sort out our housing crisis. Imagine cutting out the daily commute for ever!We didn’t have to hug people. Indeed, we were barred by law from hugging people. Or kissing them on the bloody cheek, like everyone in the media world does. That, by itself, was a huge bonus for me.My wish is that we take some of that stuff from lockdown and make it the new normal. Live at a quieter, gentler pace. Continue to eat at home — and support our local corner shops. Use the car less. Spend less money on a whole load of b******s we don’t really need. Use aeroplanes not at all, preferably. Right now, the Government has given us licence to go out and do stuff.Here’s my plea. Let’s do a bit less stuff than we used to. Let’s remain kind of half in and half out of lockdown. Whether Covid is still around or not. We’ll end up happier as a result.ONE thing Captain Tom showed us, as he walked around his garden as he approached the age of , is that it’s never too late to make a dference.Bob Dylan is just a young whippersnapper by Tom’s standards.But at the age of  he has just made his finest album in at least three decades, and probably more. Rough And Rowdy Ways is a joy to listen to – and I’d given up on the bloke in the s.If I ever reach  I intend to make a grime album with Rihanna. Get your orders in now.The United Nations has decided to give them to Mauritius. That’s because the islands are nearer Mauritius than they are to the UK. On that basis we could have a good claim to owning Belgium. The islands are important to the UK militarily. And we should keep them. The UN has given us deadlines to hand them over to a country that never owned them. What we should do instead is leave the crooked UN.EXCLUDED from the Government’s loosening of lockdown are Britain’s vibrant community of werewolves and vampires.“It is all very well biting someone’s neck, or ripping their lungs out while howling loudly,” a scientist advising the Government probably said. “But when they do this there is the risk that the virus could be passed on via droplets from the creature’s mouth. Or indeed paws – werewolves do not have a good record of using hand-sanitiser.”By contrast, zombies were praised for their social-distancing technique. “Whenever you see them they are always walking two metres apart with their hands outstretched and bits of flesh falling off their faces,” the same scientist probably added.A spokesman for the National Association of Lycanthropescommented: “This is typical of the prejudice we werewolves face and amounts to discrimination. Actually, I thought I had the virus a few weeks ago. Nasty cough and so on.“But I’m all right nooooowwwwwwooooo.”THE day after the woke ninnies at Warners withdrew the great Hollywood film Gone With The Wind because of “race issues”, guess what happened  Yup, it became the No bestselling film on Amazon. Better still, it reached No in the AppleiTunes chart for TV and film. Not bad for a movie made more than  years ago, huh I suppose it could have been “progressives” buying the film so that they would have something to be outraged about. Or maybe the Ku Klux Klan Film Club has a bigger membership than we thought.More likely though is that people loathe censorship. They don’t like being told what they can and can’t watch. Truth be told it hasn’t been for a good  years. And the process accelerated under Magic Grandpa and his front bench of mouth-breathing dingbats. Now it’s the well-orf who support Labour. And the poor who vote Conservative. But there aren’t enough people called Olly and Poppy in the country, which is why Labour hasn’t won an election for  years. Unless it reconnects with the people it was set up to support, the working class, it won’t win one for another few decades either.A SOCIAL media site had a big hit when it asked people to reveal things they regretted about getting married. The site, Whisper, was inundated with replies. Most were kind of: “I just wish I hadn’t married the fat bastard, full stop.”But some wished they’d had a fling with someone of the same sex first, or felt aggrieved they hadn’t checked out the in-laws first. That was quite a big issue. title: pubs reopening laws summer drinking
story: NEW laws to be rushed through within days will allow a summer of drinking in streets, car parks and other outdoor spaces to help pubs bounce back from months in lockdown.It will allow thousands more pubs, restaurants and cafes to serve customers outside by July  rather than requiring y planning applications.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe new Business and Planning Bill will also relax planning permission rules to make it easier and quicker to arrange car boot sales, summer fetes and outdoor markets.It will double the amount of time that planning permissions last for these temporary events and allow ‘temporary structures’ such as marquees and street trading stalls to stay up for up to  days.Iniduals and businesses will have greater power to use their land for temporary retail activities in a bid to inject much-needed le into local economies across England.It will also help the fight against the virus by encouraging people to be outdoors, where the risk of spreading the virus is much lower.Ministers hope it will lead to a surge in al fresco dining and drinking.Temporary chances to licensing laws will allow many more licences premises such as pubs and restaurants to sell alcohol for consumption off their premises.Customers will be able to buy their drinks from a pub and consume them where, making social distancing easier.Pubs and restaurants will be able to use car parks and terraces as dining and drinking areas - enabling customers to enjoy their drinks and food outside.Government sources said the move will given an “immediate and much-needed boost to many businesses” as they prepare to reopen on July  after  days shut during lockdown.But the Government has dropped plans to scrap Sunday Trading rules that limit the opening hours for shops after Tory rebels and Labour threatened to torpedo the whole bill.  It means the bill is likely to sail through Parliament next week - in time for the lting of lockdown measures on July .A government source said: “It’s about kickstarting this whole hospitality and retail industry beyond bricks and mortar shops over the busy summer period.“The Government will introduce new laws giving people greater freedom over how they use their land by doubling the amount of time that activities like that temporary structures can be placed on land without permission.”Meanwhile it emerged that the PM’s top aide Dominic Cummings has vowed to overhaul the civil service after concluding the Whitehall machine has been exposed by the coronavirus pandemic.The ConservativeHome website reported that he told an internal government meeting that the Cabinet Office will be stripped of powers after being found wanting during the crisis.Mr Cummings is said to have told fellow government aides: “A hard rain is coming”.Meanwhile Downing Street indicated that extra support could be offered to theatres in England which have been ordered to remain closed for live performances. The Prime Ministers official spokesman said: We are talking to the arts sector and considering ways in which we might be able to support them in addition to the unprecedented financial assistance we have already given.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: benidorm new normal holiday sanitiser beaches
story: In C Benidorm I found that old ritual of claiming your spot on the beach with your towel is no more.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesTo bagsy your well-earned piece of golden sand you’ll soon have to make a booking by app.And, along with cheap booze and Full English, the bars in the Costa Blanca resort are serving up temperature tests, shoe disinfectant and sanitiser stations.Desperate for theof British tourists, Benidorm has carved up Poniente and Levante beaches into , ft x ft taped off plots — with a maximum of four people allowed in each square.There’ll even be an area reserved for the over-s marked in green.One local moaned that under the new system you can either pay £ and get a sunbed and sunshade or “get put in a square like a pig”.But from a beach square she shared with three friends, student Paula Aquado, , told me: “It feels safe and it’s great to be on the beach again despite the restrictions.”Police patrol the beaches to check on social distancing. Monitors at beach entrances count the number of people entering and douse the walkways with disinfectant.I had taken one of the first Ryanair flights to Alicante from Britain this week as Spain threw open its doors to UK tourists.Early morning flyers formed long, socially-distanced queues at security for flights to Portugal, Spain, Bulgaria and Hungary. In face masks and using sanitiser dispensers dotted around Luton airport, travellers kept their two-metre distance by following stickers on the ground.Queuing with a friend, a British plasterer in his s told me: “We decided on impulse to book the flight because we’re bored of lockdown. We haven’t even booked a hotel in Benidorm but at least you can get a beer in a bar there.”On board the half-full flight, ­passengers were ordered to wear facemasks at all times.A trolley service by masked cabin staff sold beers, wines, spirits and snacks with payment by card only.At Alicante airport, border guards checked passports behind perspex screens.Passengers had to fill out contact tracing forms giving their home and holiday addresses, email and phone number before passing through thermal imaging cameras.At arrivals the Cooper family had a tearful reunion. Mum Kirsty, an expat translator, wept as she greeted sons Jayden, , and Jack, , who had been unable to fly back from the UK during lockdown.Kirsty, , said: “I’m just happy to see my boys again.”At Benidorm’s four-star Los Alamos Hotel, I was greeted by mask-wearing reception staff who asked me to disinfect my hands.Guests — who must wear a mask or maintain a .m distance — are required to sign an indemnity form promising that they will abide by social distancing rules or face being kicked out of the hotel.A sticker taped to my room door and its lintel said: “Room cleaned and sealed for your protection.”Guests trooped down to breakfast in masks and were given a dollop of hand sanitiser before joining a socially-distanced queue for grub.The all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet was no more. Staff cooked up omelettes and serve cereal to order.The masks come off at your table so you can eat. In the bar there were virtual menus accessed by phone app.Manager Maria Sanchez, , said: “We’re ready to welcome our British friends back.”Many bars and restaurants remained shuttered before the expected influx of Brits next month.At the Kai Beach bar, drinkers’ temperatures were taken before entering.Then shoes were sanitised and hands doused with gel.At Jumping Jacks, a handful of expats sipped lager on tables m apart after sanitising their hands.Engineer Dale Oldfield, , from Rochdale, who arrived in Benidorm where he has a caravan on Monday, said: “After months of lockdown, it’s great to have a beer in a pub and a steak in restaurant.”Benidorm lures more than a million British holidaymakers a year —  per cent of its foreign visitors. title: school return pupil bubble cap doubles
story: Under current rules, class numbers are capped at  and social distancing measures leave heads with a logistical nightmare requiring double the teaching space.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut from the autumn primary school pupils will not be required to keep apart from others in their own “protective bubble”, just stay away from other groups.One of the first schools to fully reopen in Britain has made passionate calls for others to follow suit — and urged “isive” unions to get on board.St Paul’s CofE Primary in Swanley, Kent, welcomed back nearly all of its  children on Monday thanks to shrewd social distancing and hygiene measures.The school’s chiefs put a marquee in their playing field to create extra space — and supplied portaloos and mobile hand washing facilities to keep kids safe.Dferent classes are kept apart with their own inidual entrances and exits. And eager children have ed straight back into lessons under strict social distancing rules without hassle.Thecomes in spite of teaching unions pouring scorn over moves to get all kids safely back in class by September.Headteacher Ben Hulme said tonight: “Schools like us have shown it can be done safely for both children and staff.“This is a time when unions, schools and headteachers should all be pulling together to get children back in class. To be isive makes it really dficult to get back to some safe normality.“There have been many reports about how lockdown has affected children’s mental health and emotional wellbeing — and how there’s potential for damage to be donewe don’t move quickly. That really spurred us on to get something together — and it’s working very well.“We’re really pleased to be back and I’d encourage other schools to do the samethey can.”Under the new plans, the Government aims to form “year group bubbles” in secondary schools.This would stop pupils mingling with teenagers from other year groups, while allowing classes toto their normal size.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson hailed St Paul’s safe and swt— and called on others to take “full advantage” of the chance to open again.He told The Sun: “We have given primary schools the flexibility to bring back more children — where they can do so within our protective measures — and it’s fantastic to see some schools taking full advantage of that to maximise their capacity and invite back all pupils.”Anne Longfield, the Children’s Commissioner for England, heaped praise on St Paul’s — and urged other schools to follow its lead.She said: “This is a real achievement and great to see teachers working with parents to get the whole school open safely before the summer break.”The Government originally ­pledged to get all primary schools back in action for at least a month before June . But ministers had to ditch the plans over fears that the target would not be met.Militant unions have been accused of playing politics and stopping kids ing to class, instead of putting their welfare first.Department for Education data revealed , pupils were in class last month — down from . million on a normal school day.Latest figures show approximately . million attended school last Thursday — . per cent of pupils who normally attend." rel"noreferrer noopener"Boris Johnson told MPs yesterday that education would restart fully at the start of autumn term.It was welcome news for millions of parents who have endured three months of lockdown — many juggling full-time jobs with childcare and home-schooling. Secondary schools in England have been allowed to reopen for Years ,  and  since June .Nursery and pre-school children, plus pupils in Reception, Year  and Year , started toon June .But not all schools have reopened fully. Some do not have the staff and others do not have the space.Current government guidance for schools does not require kids to socially distance within their bubble, but many schools are ignoring the advice, insisting on all pupils remaining two-metres apart.The rules planned for September would make clear that social distancing would not be required within bubbles.Instead, kids will be encouraged to limit contact with each other.Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will.The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Fourteen staff tested positive for Covid- from the workforce of  at its plant in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, forcing the -hour closure.The plant produces canned and pouch products including baked beans, soups, pulses, pasta and vegetables and is the latest food processing factory to be hit by outbreaks in recent days.A Princes spokesman said: “Our priority is the wellbeing and safety of our colleagues. story: It could shed light on the evolution of Earth.The exoplanet named Au Mic b, is much too hot to host le, say astronomers.Its sun is only  to million years old — roughly  times younger than ours.Nasa’s Dr Tom Barclay said: “Studying this planet can give us insight into how our own solar system formed.”About , miles wide, Au Mic b is likely to be primarily comprised of gases — and may be the shape of a teardrop.Co-author Dr Jonathan Gagne, of Montreal University, said AU Microscopii has a strong magnetic field - and will be very active.He said: Its a small star - with only about  per cent of the Suns mass.Astrophysicists have been searching for exoplanets in this solar system for more than a decade.Dr Gagne added: It took nearly  years to find AU Mic b.The numerous spots and eruptions on the surface of its sun hampered its detection - which was already complicated by the presence of the disc.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cop on sick pay moonlighted as undertaker
story: A disciplinary  heard PC Phillip Smallcombe, , led the cortege at funerals instead of pounding the beat.He quit South Wales Police after his cheating was discovered and has now been banned from being a police officer.Mr John Bassett, chair of the misconduct , said: He had failed to seek authorisation for this business interest and when he did, the application was not authorised.A police officer is required to declare their business interests, which Mr Smallcombe did not do until he had been involved in the running of the business for a year, and continued working after an application was submitted and not approved.Police officers are allowed outside business interests as long as they are authorised and do not conflict with police work. title: music britain collapsing covid 19
story: And now I’m scratching my head wondering how cinemas are able to welcome visitors before we’ve worked out how to listen to music together.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive music is vital, not just for fuelling our dreams but for the reality of our economy, too.The live music sector is expecting to suffer £million in losses this year, which is  per cent of its annual contribution to the UK economy.From arena concerts to your local pub singer, ALL live music has been silenced.But the Government doesn’t seem to be taking it seriously, with music way down the list of priorities and no date in the diary for when we will be able to go to a gig again.We can’t afford to take our music scene for granted.Since the birth of rock ’n’ roll, Britain has dominated global tastes in pop music.Part of The Beatles’ legacy is that they transformed the British record business from a cottage industry into a global phenomenon.When they signed to Parlophone, early in the Sixties, one man and his secretary ran the entire label.George Martin signed the band, produced, manufactured and promoted their early records and, over the brief course of the band’s existence, saw the whole thing go through the roof.It was comparable to the dotcom boom or internet shopping.Many now see the Rolling Stones as the greatest band to come out of that era for the way they have managed to continue playing to vast new audiences  years later.But the Sixties was just the start of it. The Seventies brought Led Zeppelin and countless rock bands, it gave us heavy metal and punk and Joy Division pretty much all at the same time.The biggest-selling album of the Eighties, Michael Jackson’s Thriller, was actually written by a bloke from Hull, while British greats as erse as Duran Duran and The Smiths ruled the waves.In the Cool Britannia of the Nineties, when Britpop was ringing out of radio networks worldwide, even American stars such as Madonna sought help from British producers such as Nellee Hooper and William Orbit.Then there were the Spice Girls. And Coldplay. Now we’ve got Ed Sheeran and Adele. And it doesn’t stop with artists. Love him or hate him, Simon Cowell’s TV programmes are another British global music phenomenon.But it’s live music where Britain really dominates today. Glastonbury should be taking place this weekend.I’ve played at just about every major festival on the planet, from Coachella in the US to Fuji Rock in Japan, but there is nowhere to touch Glastonbury.It is, quite simply, the greatest show on earth There is a massive ripple effect from Glastonbury. It sets a very high bar for the other  — that’s  — festivals that happen throughout the UK every single summer.And the same crews who build the stages, operate the sound systems, put up the fences and supply the bogs for Glasto are busy for the rest of the summer at other events.Now the independent festival sector is at risk of collapse thanks to the Covid shutdown.Last month, the Association of Independent Festivals , which represents  festivals in the UK, reported that  per cent of its members were facing costs that could ruin their businesses and . per cent were uninsured for Covid- related cancellations.Most of my time these days is spent planning and organising The Big Feastival, which was due to take place here on my farm in Oxfordshire this August Bank Holiday weekend.Of course I’m devastated it won’t be going ahead, but the really sad thing is that it looks like no one is going to hear any live music, new or old this summer.That’s a tragedy for the musicians who rely on gigging to make a living — as well as all the other people whose income relies on live music.The Musicians’ Union says its members have lost more than £million in income during the lockdown. Remember, that most musicians just scrape by at the best of times.Big stars are bigger than ever before, but they are the exception not the rule. When Adele releases another record there is a danger she will become so massive she will collapse into a black hole.But now bands need an audience to play to and also financial support, which used to come from record companies but now is hard to find.Records, or downloads, are basically free these days, so live shows are the only real way to make money.In the same way restaurants were already struggling before lockdown, many of Britain’s smaller live music venues were struggling too.So most of the places I played in the early days with Blur have already dis- appeared. They need to be able to open their doors again, as do festivals.It has to be possible to find a way. Just as with pubs, restaurants and cinemas, you could limit the number of people allowed into a venue.Perhaps more gigs could be seated to ensure social distancing. Not quite the same, but better than nothing.As far as the rest of the planet is concerned, Britain is represented pretty much by the Royal Family, football and music.We must keep our festival circuit alive and nurture new artists.That means we urgently have to find a way for music to be played to a live audience, evenit’s only a small one — so that we can keep meaning something to the rest of the world.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unions betrayed our kids
story: Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in  confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will. The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.PUBS with no music, singing, dancing or shouting  That’s just a library with more beer and no books.And how about visor-clad hairdressers snipping in enforced silence, with no gossip or radio It all sounds like a sci-fi dystopia of Britain. But this is the Government’s vision for our summer as it tries to save businesses while keeping us safe.To which we say: Well, good luck with that. We understand the reasoning. The scientists say all these activities pass on Covid in the breath. And they are desperate to avoid a new surge in cases.Some might see little point in a pub with the le sucked out of it. But we must use them or lose them.From July , support your local. Consider it your solemn duty.THE survey saying a quarter of furloughed workers will lose their jobs is horrying.Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. title: quarter of furloughed workers likely to lose their jobs
story: Reductions to the amount being spent on the scheme will start in September.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesA survey of , businesses on behalf of London-based lender MarketFinance Ltd found nearly  per cent planned job cuts.The poll also found that  per cent of companies plan to bring back up to half of their furloughed staff next month.The government s coronavirus job retention scheme was announced in March  allowing furloughed employees to claim  per cent of their wages up to £, a month. Businesses will be able to bring back their employees part time from July as much of the economy begins to reopen. This means staff can work a few days a week and be paid by their employer, and then remain furloughed for the rest of the week and be paid out of the public purse. But it doesnt affect your redundancy pay rightsyou are let go from your job amid the coronavirus crisis.Your employer should still carry out a fair redundancy process.You are also entitled to appeal the decision by claiming unfair dismissal within three months of being let go.If youre made redundant after your company has gone into administration you can claim redundancy pay " href"https:www.gov.uk claim-redundancy" target"_blank" rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"via Gov.uk. Employers will have to begin paying national insurance and pension contributions from August as the scheme is gradually wound down. Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced last month the scheme would be extended until October to help the economy survive the shock of the coronavirus crisis. You will be entitled to be consulted on the redundancy lay-off first and to receive a statutory redundancy payment, as long as youve been working somewhere for at least two years.Redundancy pay is capped at £ per weekHow much youre entitled to depends on your age andof service, although this is capped at  years. Youll get:Sadly, you wont be entitled to a payoutyouve been working for your employer for fewer than two years.There should be a period of collective consultation as well as time for inidual onesyour employer wants to make  or more employees redundant within  days or each other.The Office for National Statisticsestimates furlough costs around £billion a month.As bars, restaurants, pubs, hairdressers, cinemas and most other businesses in England are allowed to reopen on July , firms financial viability will be put to the test in a fight to survive after the lockdown. Businesses will have to follow strict social distancing rules -including limiting the number of people in venues at any one time, pushing companies on shoe-string budgets to the limit. According to the ONS, , people have already lost their jobs since the start of the lockdown. More than  million people have been forced to turn to Universal Credit to survive as job losses have swept the UK. Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. At which point more than two million will be added to the dole queue.That will be a bitter blow for many who have enjoyed the lockdown — some packing the beaches yesterday on what would ordinarily be a working day.The bailouts’ end in October spells devastation in particular for the young and low-paid. And it falls to Chancellor Rishi Sunak to recreate the jobs boom of the last decade.At least, post-Brexit, he will have even more tools with which to do it.From September employers will pay  percent of furloughed workers salary, as the Treasury reduces their contribution from  per cent to  per cent. story: On Tuesday, the Duchess, , and Duke of Sussex ,  – who are living in Tyler Perrys  million LA mansion – volunteered at the Homeboy Industries Café and Bakery.Photos were shared of the couples visit to the Calornia establishment, which saw them prepare food and learn about the organization behind it.Homeboy Industries shared images of Meghan and Harrys visit on social media.Thank you to Harry and Meghan, The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, for visiting and standing in kinship with our Café and Bakery teams yesterday! their Instagram caption read.Our staff were thrilled to work alongside them as they helped prepare food and learned more about our newly launched #FeedHOPE program.[It] employs our program participants to provide meals to food-insecure seniors and youth across Los Angeles in the wake of the COVID- pandemic.Megan and Harry kept things casual, donning crisp white shirts for the occasion and rolled up their sleeves.During the baking extravaganza, they made bread, folded dough, and sorted food boxes for the needy.Harper Bazaars royal editor Omid Scobie revealed that Homeboy Industries is run by Father Gregory Boyle.Former actress Meghan and her royal husband have reportedly been speaking to Boyle about the issue of racial injustice amid widespread Black Lives Matter protests.Meghan and Boyle met  years ago at a Homeboy Industry cooking workshop, where she made tamales with her mom, Doria.Boyle has worked with Meghans alma mater, Immaculate Heart High School in LA.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex were just Harry and Meghan to the homies, he said. title: uk weather forecast 34c hottest record wales
story: While the mercury is expected to soar, thunderstorms are also predicted to sweep across the country from around pm.Temperatures are tipped to rocket towards C todayas the country continues to bask in a summer heatwave.Thursday could set a new record above the hottest June day ever when temperatures hit .C in .It would also beat the hottest June day in  when highs of around C were recorded at Heathrow, West London, on June .The hottest day of the year so far was .C in May, but todays temperatures are due to soar past that.Met Office forecaster Luke Miall said: Thursday will probably be the hottest day in the region of  or  degrees.Parts of Wales could see the mercury rise to C- making it the hottest June on record in the country, surpassing the previous peak of .Con June,  .The hot spell has sparked concerns about wildfires and the wellbeing of elderly residents cooped up indoors during the UKs coronavirus lockdown.It comes as the Met Office raised its heat alert level to three and as health authorities urged sun seekers to protect themselves amid the exceptionally hot weather forecast this week.The National Fire Chiefs Councilhas warned against starting campfires which can easily get out of control.The NFCC said: The weather is forecast to improve and, although weve had our fair share of rain recently, the risk of wildfires remains.These fires are often preventable, soyou are enjoying the countryside please be wildfire-aware and look out for our advice.And fire and rescue services across the country have warned people about the hazards of cooling off by swimming in rivers and lakes." rel"noreferrer noopener"The South Wales service warned: Respect the water. Whatever your activity and your ability, the water can always catch you out. It’s easy to underestimate its power.People with elderly relatives should make sure they keep cool during the lockdown, Age UKwarned.However, there could be an increased risk of storms by the end of the week.Deputy Chief Meteorologist, Matthew Lehnert, said: We’re also seeing an increased risk of thunderstorms towards the end of the week which is expected to bring an end to the very warm and sunny weather.Thunderstorms are expected to sweep across the UK from pm on June , bringing heavy rain, lightning and hail.The storms will form in the South West and South East of England, Wales, western Scotland and Northern Ireland.A yellow weather warning for thunderstorms is in place for much of the country from Thursday to Saturday, with the threat of disruption due to flooding, lightning strikes, hail and wind.The World Meteorological Organisation definition of a heatwave is when the daily maximum temperature of more than five consecutive days exceeds the average maximum temperature by C, the normal period being -.They are most common in summer when high pressure develops across an area.High-pressure systems are slow-moving and can persist over an area for a prolonged period of time such as days or weeks.They can occur in the UK due to the location of the jet stream, which is usually to the north of the UK in the summer.This can allow high pressure to develop over the UK resulting in persistent dry and settled weather.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk pubs reopening july 4 rules regulations laws
story: As the government continues to ease the coronavirus lockdown restrictions pubs and bars will be able to reopen but a few restrictions will be in be place.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesYour local boozer is likely to reopen on July  after Prime Minister Boris Johnson gave the green light for them to reopen in a boost to the hospitality industry.Mr Johnson announced that pubs will be among those allowed to reopen on July  in England.Boozers had to shut back in March, with many issuing concerns they could go out of business.Mr Johnson has also revealed pubs will be allowed to serve drinks outside in a bid to boost the economy.Some pubs have been allowed to partially reopen in June using outdoor market-style stalls.While the doors of your favourite pub may be open on July  things will not be the same as before lockdown and you will have to observe a number of restrictions before you can sink that first pub pint.The two-metre social distancing rule has been reduced to one metre plus - which means one metre minimum distance when not possible to otherwise.The plus means that the public must also take other precautionary measures to limit any potential spread.With social distancing in mind, the look of your favourite boozer could be very dferent.Tables will also be placed two metres apart and screens will be erected at bars to protect staff.Limits on customers will also be in place, with people only let inthere is a seat for them.Bars and restaurants will have to keep a record of everyone who visits before being served under new plans.Personal details are kept on file for four weeks there and are used to contact peopleone of the patrons later is hit with coronavirus.Bar staff will have to wear masks and gloves at all times while working.It’s unlikely you’ll be able to simply walk into a pub on the spur of the moment and have a pint, certainly in the first few days of reopening.Drinkers have been warned that you will have to book a table beforehandyou want to go to the pub on July .Queuing up at a crowded bar is strictly out and you will have to order your round of drinks using a downloaded app.A one-way system of sorts will be introduced with customers entering via one door and having to leave via another.New laws to be rushed through within days will allow a summer of drinking in streets, car parks and other outdoor spaces to help pubs bounce back from months in lockdown.The new Business and Planning Bill will also relax planning permission rules to make it easier and quicker to arrange car boot sales, summer fetes and outdoor markets.It will double the amount of time that planning permissions last for these temporary events and allow ‘temporary structures’ such as marquees and street trading stalls to stay up for up to  days.It will also help the fight against the virus by encouraging people to be outdoors, where the risk of spreading the virus is much lower.Temporary changes to licensing title: uk hot weather advice windows open shut keep cool
story: Here’s what you need to know about when to open your windows and when to keep them closed.It really comes down tothe temperature outside is hotter or colder than inside.The advice states: “Keep windows closed when it’s hotter outside than inside, but open themthe room gets too hot”.Pale or thin curtains or blinds should be closed but should be kept openthey are dark-coloured or thick or you have metal blinds as they can make a room hotter.Putting something reflective on the outside of the glass can bounce the heat away, keeping the room cool – similar to the screens that go on the windshield of your car.The general advice is to keep windows open at night as it is cooler outside.But for security reasons downstairs windows should be locked when you go out or go to bed.It will also stop wild animals or neighbour’s pets creeping in who are looking for a cosy bed for the night.The NHS has several tips for keeping your house and yourself cool during a scorching heatwave.Keep windows that are exposed to the sun closed during the day, and open windows at night when the temperature has droppedKeep rooms cool by using shades or reflective material outside the windows. If this is not possible, use light-coloured curtains and keep them closed If possible, move into a cooler room, especially for sleepingIf you have concerns about an uncomfortably hot house thats affecting your health or someone s, get medical advice.It also recommends taking cool baths or showers and regularly splashing yourself with cool water.The full NHS advice can be found " rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"here.You can also get help from the environmental health office at your local authority.They can inspect a home for hazards to health, including excess heat.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leicester city demarai gray girlfriend mansion raid worcestershire
story: The raid at the Premier League players mansion in Worcestershire was part of a six-month crime spree.Grays girlfriend Emma Hickman was confronted by balaclava-clad intruders, one wielding a machete, as she lay in bed naked with the couples six-week-old child.She was so terried she later moved out.Aaron Jones, , and Tyler Greenway, , were both found guilty of conspiracy to rob following a trial.Jones was also convicted of conspiracy to possess a firearm.They had both previously admitted conspiracy to burgle and theft.Nicholas Rothero, , and his son Cory Rothero, , had both previouslyadmitted conspiracy to rob, steal, burgle, and conspiracy to possess afirearm.Darren Sadler, , of Bartley Green, had previously pleaded guilty to conspiracy to rob.Jones was jailed for  years, Nicholas Rothero for  years andSaddler for four years.Saddlers sentence was ordered to run consecutively to a term of tenyears and eight months he is already serving for robbery.Both Cory Rothero and Greenway were each sentenced to  years in ayoung offenders institution.Michael Duck QC, prosecuting, told Birmingham Crown Court: Thedefendants are a group of organised criminals. Between October and April  they committed a series of armed robberies andburglaries at commercial and residential premises.He said they used serious violence which escalated over time.They went to signicant s to disguise themselves and chosevulnerable targets such as small stores which had a limited amount ofstaff, Mr Duck said.They arrived in stolen cars which were used to get away at the fastest speed possible.Mr Duck said: They arrived mob-handed, conspicuously armed withknives, making a lot of noise and terrying those they encountered.They raided safes and cashpoints.The first shop targeted was a One Stop in Bristol Road North,Northfield, on October . They made off with £, after wielding ahammer, kne and crow bar and workers to the back of the premises.The gang also netted arond £, after terrorising two employees atthe Barnt Green Inn pubb and snatched £,-worth of mobiles from aphone shop where staff were threatened.Saddler was arrested following a struggle with police after a raid ona Car Phone Warehouse.But that did not deter the close knit team, who attacked a TescoExpress in Northfield armed themselves with weapons including a gun.Describing the attack on the home of the -year-old footballer, Mr Duck said there was evidence that the premises had been deliberately targeted.He went on: The male occupant of the premises was not there that day.He was at work.Members of the gang, armed with knives, parked alongside a hedgebefore breaking in.They stayed briefly downstairs before going upstairs where -year-oldMiss Hickman was trying to catch up on some sleep.She was woken from her sleep and greeted by the sight of a man whowas obviously masked and carrying a large black kne, Mr Duck said.The intruder, Nicholas Rothero, was then joined by Jones and CoryRothero and one of them picked up a gold kne from the side of the bedwhich her partner used to open parcels and envelopes.She was completely trapped and confined with the confines of her bedroom.Mr Duck said they knew something about her boyfriend and expressedsurprise he was not there.During the trial, Miss Hickman said the raiders demanded jewellery and money.She said she had been petried and they had accused her partner ofbeing a gangbanger and demanded to know when he was coming back.They snatched her Rolex and told her the footballer could fork out foranother one.When she told them her mother was on the way, the men told her hershed get hurt when she arrived.The raiders also took keys to Gray’s Mercedes only to discover it wasnot on the driveway before they fled with £,-worth of cash andjewellery in a stolen car.Passing sentence, Judge Richard Bond said the offences were executedruthlessly and with a real degree of success.He said that on two occasions guns were used to instil fear intovictims so they would co-operate.A feature is the professionalism in the way the offending was carriedout, he told the gangsters.Full disguises were used by the offenders to cause victims to beintimidated when confronted by you.Victims were made to feel scared and helpless and on some occasionsfearful for their lives.Your professionalism was also demonstrated by the speed of the offences.You targeted vulnerable premises. The sophistication of youroffending was also demonstrated by the wearing of gloves to ensurethat finger prints were not left behind.CCTV shows on several occasions members of staff cowering in terrorduring the course of robberies.Referring to the attack on Grays home, he said: This property wasdeliberately targeted by you because of who lived there.Jones made inquiries on the internet about the person.You believed there would be rich pickings at the property. You weretargeting high-value goods.Miss Hickman could not have been more vulnerable in her own home.She bravely gave evidence and it is dficult to forget the obviousterror she felt when confronted by three masked men in her bedroom.She was traumatised by what happened and has moved out of the house.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
