title: A glance at Castlewellan teenager’s debut book
story: Sixteen year-old Dara McAnulty from Castlewellan has been universally praised for his debut book, Diary of a Young Naturalist, which was launched last month. His book has been described in The Independent as ldquoone of the finest pieces of modern nature writing in recent years. In this extract the autistic teenager shares his joy of the natural world on a day out to Murlough with his sister and brother.OUR garden is thrumming with birds today: coal, blue and great tits, blackbird, thrush, magpie, jackdaw, rook, all of them revelling on the grass, pecking at the feeders.I could happily watch them all day but rain is coming from the east, so we decide to go west to the coast at Murlough to stay in the sunshine. I usually despise being in the sun. I find its light too bright, its heat too hot, and it can make me feel astherersquos nowhere to hide. But with this rain coming, I feel like being on the dunes at Murlough, pressed by warmth and sea breezes.The ancient dune system here is six thousand years old, fragile and spectacular. The unusually high dunes were formed in the late th and th centuries by massive storms, and were used by people in the Middle Ages as rabbit warrens to provide them with meat and pelts.Grazing rabbits encouraged the grassy heathland here, but when myxomatosis first broke out in the s, as it did in other parts of Ireland and Britain, the population was almost wiped out. With fewer rabbits, sea buckthorn and sycamore could grow, turning heath to scrubland. Now the National Trust have intervened at Murlough, managing the landscape so it reverts back to heath mdash and judging from the copious pings, it looks like the rabbits are thriving again, too.The day is sparkling, the wind is shaking and shaping the clouds. Lorcan and Blaacutethnaid want to swim, so I stroll along the beach with my binoculars. Shapes out at sea stop me: a trinity of torpedoing gannets. They swoop, wheel and suddenly drop, spiralling until the last second when they transform into arrows before hitting the water.Swallows are overhead ndash I can see their small bodies so clearly, weightless and constantly moving. I feel myself rising with them.My dark, knotted thoughts seem to be staying away at the moment. I feel as free as the gannets and swallows. If they can live their lives, shouldnrsquot I do the same  Can I breathe and live and also fight  The natural world mdash which includes us mdash is facing such enormous challenges that itrsquos easy to become overwhelmed and depressed. But we must fix them, andIrsquom no longer here, alive, I canrsquot be part of the solution.What is it thatrsquos holding me back  Anxiety  Depression  Autism  These are the shackles. Surely, I can break free. Or at least I can accept these things as part of me. I have no answers, but the lightness of these thoughts and these days weave my body and mind with everything around me. The only thing that I am really bound to is nature ndash as we all are.Lorcan and Blaacutethnaid are running towards me, and I run to them, and then we run together, exultant. We slow down in unison, all feeling the same pull of the large peculiar shells dotted around the beach. We each pick one up and hold them outstretched, delicate porcelain in our hands.They look like pale planets, pockmarked with symmetrical lines. I rattle mine, listening to the whisper of sand and the past. These are sea potatoes mdash a type of sand-burrowing sea urchin mdash with pocks that once held spines and a bleached calcium carbonate shell that could so easily shatter on land or at sea. Each one is a miracle. So many miracles washed up at once.We start to collect them and Lorcan decides to name three of the best specimens Sandy, Sam and Sandra. He holds a conversation with them, three sea potatoes, which makes us laugh so hard that tears well up and almost flow, and wersquore still laughing as a warm rain starts to fall on us.Under dark skies, I feel completely unburdened of any doubts in my own abilities to help our planet. Instead, I feel energised and ready. Sopping wet and cold and with chattering teeth, still giggling madly, I feel hope pouring in the rain. Being myself is enough.Diary of a Young Naturalist by Dara McAnulty is published by Little Tollerand can be bought online, or at No Alibis bookshop in Belfast..prettyPhoto

title: A lifetime of capturing Ireland’s scenic beauty
story: AMATEUR photographer Chris Laverty spent a letime capturing Irelandrsquos scenic beauty.The former Queenrsquos University computer centre manager travelled extensively, always with his camera, and always with an eye for the magic of the countryside around him. His images run into many thousands of prints, negatives, and slides.On the eve of what would have been Chrisrsquos th birthday tomorrow and following his recent death in February , his we Moya and family have shared with the Recorder a glimpse of some of his local collection.When he retired and moved to Downpatrick, he was transfixed by the richness of Lecale and the surrounding area, particularly the natural beauty of the Mournes.ldquoPhotography was more than a hobby for Chris, said Moya. ldquoHe always had a keen eye for detail which shone through in his impressive photographs.ldquoHis photos will always hold so many memories that the family will treasure forever. He loved the area and his passion for it shines through in an extensive collection.Moya added: ldquoChris was greatly loved and will always remain in our hearts. We hope people will enjoy his photographs..prettyPhoto

title: Call for visitors of local beauty spots to tidy up after themselves
story: A LOCAL councillor has appealed to day trippers visiting local beauty spots to tidy up after themselves.Sinn Fein councillor Oonagh Hanlon says that while holidaying at home is great news for local businesses she has urged visitors to respect the environment around them.She said: ldquoAs lockdown measures are eased and foreign holidays are not available, many people are choosing to visit many Co Down beauty spots.ldquoThe dumping of disposable barbecues, bottles, toilet waste and other litter has increased.ldquoVisitors must take their rubbish home to be disposed of safely and responsibly. Cllr Hanlon added that litter thrown out of car windows, or lying on the ground is not acceptable.ldquoNow, more than ever, it is vital that visitors care for the area and leave nothing but footprints behind them.Cllr Hanlon added: ldquoWe all hope the tourist economy will begin to reopen soon and cater for visitors, but they need to follow guidelines..prettyPhoto

title: Call to restore key services at Downe
story: HEALTH chiefs have this week reiterated their commitment to restore emergency services at the Downe Hospital.The confirmation comes after politicians and hospital campaigners ramped up calls to restore a number of key services temporarily closed as part of sweeping changes implemented by the South Eastern Trust in April as part of their response to managing the coronavirus pandemic.Health chiefs closed the Downpatrick hospitalrsquos emergency department, with critical care staff and some equipment relocated to the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald.In addition, the Downersquos day procedure unit, outpatients department and minor injuries service were also closed.The health trust said it had to prepare ldquofor the biggest challenge it has ever faced and needed to reshape its hospitals and other services on a temporary basis to maximise its ability to ldquomanage the surge in demand for services due to Covid-.With the situation starting to improve and indications that the emergency department at Newryrsquos Daisy Hill hospital is to reopen after it was temporarily closed by the Southern Health Trust to help manage coronavirus cases, calls are increasing for the Downersquos ED to reopen.The trust has confirmed that it is ldquoprogressing plans in accordance with the Department of Healthrsquos strategic framework for rebuilding health and social care services.And officials have confirmed that as part of the first planning phase, the endoscopy service and other day case surgical work has already recommenced at the Downpatrick hospitalrsquos day procedure unit.In addition, they say that further plans for the restoration of services are expected to be published at the start of next month.However, health officials say they are unable to provide a ldquodefinitive timeline as to when the Downersquos emergency department will be reinstated ldquodue to the continuing threat of Covid- and the ongoing planning required.In a statement, the South Eastern Trust said it remains its intention to restore the Downersquos emergency department services.ldquoIf the Covid- virus continues to present the challenges it currently does, this will require two separate pathways within existing facilities for Covid- and non-Covid- patients, the statement continues. ldquoThis will also be heavily reliant on staff availability, which continues to be limited at present.Trust officials say they appreciate the concerns of the local community and the assurances it is keen to receive from them.ldquoWe are working to rebuild services as quickly as possible. As we work to do so, our absolute priority will be to keep our patients, service users and staff safe. the statement adds.The health trustrsquos insistence that emergency services will be restored at the Downe comes ahead of a meeting with a Sinn Fein delegation to discuss the issue.Spearheaded by South Down MP, Chris Hazzard, the delegation will be seeking assurances that all services will be restored to their previous level.Ahead of the meeting, Mr Hazzard said that due to the pandemic, the local community was left without access to vital services at the Downe due to the health systemrsquos response to coronavirus which ldquorequired what amounted to extraordinary measures for an extraordinary time.The MP said the Downe was left ldquounrecognisable as emergency and outpatient services, amongst others, closed from the end of March.ldquoWhere required, all available staff and equipment from these units was also requisitioned for use in other parts of the South Eastern Trust area, he continued.ldquoIn agreeing to the radical reconfiguration of the Downe, the community made a big sacrice in order to accommodate the unprecedented demands made by both health trusts in the fight against Covid-.Insisting that it was the right thing to do at the right time, Mr Hazzard said there is now an onus on trust management to respond in kind to the community.He said the recently published recovery plans have delayed the restoration of vital services to the community, causing signicant concern amongst many who fear that ldquotemporary closure might inevitably mean permanent removal.Mr Hazzard said the Sinn Fein delegation will be calling for the full restoration of services at the Downe and will also be meeting with the chief executive of the Southern Trust to call for services removed from Newryrsquos Daisy Hill hospital to be reinstated.Rowallane DUP councillors are also demanding the full restoration of services at the Downe Hospital, highlighting the importance of reopening the emergency department as soon as possible.Cllr Billy Walker said it was ironic that within hours of confirmation that the Downpatrick ED would not reopen at this stage, the South Eastern Trust revealed via social media that the Ulster Hospitalrsquos emergency department was extremely busy.ldquoThis is nothing new, he declared. ldquoThere is a clear need for the Downersquos emergency department to reopen now. Having this facility available can help ease the pressure on other EDs and we cannot understand why there is not increased investment in Downpatrick.ldquoWe all understood the temporary closure of services at the Downe to allow health chiefs to respond to the global pandemic, but the time for those services to be reinstated is now. The people of this district demand and expect nothing less, he added..prettyPhoto

title: Calls for start date as Mallon backs scheme
story: WORK on Ballynahinchrsquos new multi-million pound bypass could potentially start before next March.Stormont roads minister Nichola Mallon has included the near two-mile scheme in a list of strategic projects that will be progressed during the current financial year, with the Ballynahinch project effectively ready to proceed.Never before has the Ballynahinch scheme been accorded such a high priority by the Department of Infrastructure, with all attention now focusing on confirmation of a start date.Major progress has been made over recent years to advance the scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads with the bypass designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the by-pass where the major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.The bypass is the single biggest road scheme ever proposed for the district with suggestions that it will take at least  months to construct, with roads officials insisting that the scheme will reduce journey times and improve road safety.Announcing her decision to progress the Ballynahinch bypass and a number of other flagship road projects over the next year, Ms Mallon said her plan is to aid economic recovery and community transformation.She has asked her officials to press ahead with the bypass and other major road schemes in other parts of the Province, including the southern relief road in Newry, the Enniskillen and Cookstown bypasses and junction improvements along the A.ldquoThese strategic and flagship road improvement schemes span Northern Ireland and will deliver for many communities and help to address regional imbalance, said the minister.ldquoMany communities across the North have waited a long time for progress to be made and while Covid- has left considerable challenges, I have been determined to get the wheels in motion and get these schemes back on track.The roads minister said each of the schemes are at a dferent stage, explaining that she has asked her officials to bring forward plans to press ahead in the short and longer term.Ms Mallon added: ldquoWhile these are uncertain and dficult times, with a focus on green recovery, I also recognise that our road infrastructure needs updated to relieve traffic in towns, explore options for active travel and reshape our places to deliver towns and cities that work for our communities and aid economic growth.ldquoI hope to be in a position in the coming weeks to provide a further update on the progress being made.South Down MP Chris Hazzard has welcomed the ministerial commitment to deliver the new Ballynahinch bypass.A former roads minister in a previous Northern Ireland Executive, he has urged Ms Mallon to deliver on what he described as her ldquonew found commitment to the multi-million pound scheme by committing resources and commencing construction work as soon as possible.The MP claimed Ms Mallonrsquos commitment to ldquodevelop the eagerly-awaited project last Friday came after she had ldquofailed to include the bypass scheme in her departmentrsquos budget statement earlier in the week.ldquoThe local community will be relieved that the roads minister hasnrsquot forgotten about the Ballynahinch bypass after a disappointing few days following her capital budget plans were published earlier in the week, without mention of the local scheme, continued Mr Hazzard.ldquoI welcome the fact that the minister has finally now publicly acknowledged and committed to further develop the scheme. However, bearing in mind the scheme is all but shovel ready, this should be a simple case of signing the commencement orders with construction starting as soon as possible.Mr Hazzard said the roads minister has a capital budget of more than poundm to be spent this year, suggesting that very few projects are as advanced as the Ballynahinch bypass.ldquoThere is no logical reason why this long overdue project canrsquot get the green light for construction as a matter of priority, he said.The MP added: ldquoIn light of the severe economic impact of Covid- and the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, the commencement of this scheme would be a welcome step towards improving both our local economy and the wellbeing of our community..prettyPhoto

title: Darragh Cross residents bring cheer to local residential home
story: RESIDENTS from Oakland Court in Darragh Cross made the most of the lockdown by having socially distanced nights of entertainment while helping the residents of a nearby residential home.From hosting fun events such as bingo and discos, they raised pound for Willowview Residential Home in Saintfield.Oakland Court residents would like to thank Darragh Crossrsquo Vivo shop for its donation of prize hampers and everyone who donated prizes and gts.In turn, all residents and staff of Willowview Residential Home would like to say pay their gratitude to to all the residents of Oakland Court and Darragh Cross Vivo for their kindness and thoughtfulness..prettyPhoto

title: DNA testing on dog dirt
story: SENIOR Newry, Mourne and Down Council officers say they will need time to research the issue of using DNA testing on dog dirt in a bid to trace animals which are allowed to use public areas as open air toilets.Members of the local authorityrsquos Neighbourhood Services Committee will discuss the issue at their virtual meeting later today.A motion on the issue tabled by Rowallane councillor Patrick Brown at the March meeting of the full council was referred to the local authority committee for discussion.Dog dirt poses a major health risk, especially to children, who could potentially lose their sight as a result of coming into contact with it.Cllr Brown said there was a need to consider innovative ways of tackling the issue which has been raised on a regular basis by elected representatives across the local authorityrsquos seven DEAs.He is keen for the local authority to investigate the viability of using DNA testing in a bid to identy offenders and aid enforcement officers to dish out fines.Cllr Brown is also eager for council officials to draw upon best practice from other councils who have introduced such a scheme in a bid to crack down on the dog fouling issue.In addition, he wants the local authority to roll out what he has described as an ldquoenhanced public awareness campaign focusing on the dangers of dog fouling.Ahead of tonightrsquos council meeting, officers are recommending that Cllr Brownrsquos motion is agreed to allow them time to research similar schemes which have been introduced where.In addition, officers say that they will need to understand the time and resources required to implement such a scheme locally beforereporting back to the council committee.Politicians, who have previously asked for more enforcement staff to be deployed across the district to deal with the dog fouling problem, say the highly contentious issue is one of the single most complained about problems in the area.They say that despite valiant efforts over recent years by council officials and others, the issue has not been adequately addressed..prettyPhoto

title: Drive in assembly at Crossgar primary school
story: CEDAR Integrated Primary School in Crossgar has said farewell to its P pupils.Staff held a drive-in leavers ceremony for the outgoing P class last Friday.Parents and carers were invited to park in the playground and watch the  pupils receive folders of their work from their time at Cedar.They also received a survival kit for lsquobig schoolrsquo, as well as trophies for sports, arts and ICT,. Fittingly, the coveted Endeavour Cup was awarded to the whole class.While the weather was less than kind, it seemed nothing could dampen the spirits of children, parents and staff as they came together to celebrate.School principal Hilary Crichton praised the children for their forbearance in unique circumstances, and reiterated the feelings of everyone when she said that the class would be very much missed.Mrs Crichton thanked her staff for preparing the special occasion in such a short space of time.ldquoOn an emotional day at Cedar, everyone was sad to see the P pupils leave for the last time, she said.ldquoWe all wish each and every one of them the very best of luck as they move on to their new schools in the autumn term.rsquoOne pupil said: ldquoWe were blessed and privileged to be part of this class and can sincerely say we will miss Cedar IPS.A parent, Gemma Barr, said ldquoWersquore all very lucky that the hard working staff were able to facilitate their leavers assembly.Shemaine Kerr, chair of the board of governors, thanked the staff and wished the children the ldquobest of luck..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C June 17%2C 2000
story: NEWCASTLE mdash Two week-old Kirsty McKibben, from Newcastle, is alive today because of the skills of the medical staff at the Downpatrick Maternity Unit who kept her alive minutes after she was born at the side of a road.Had the hospital been closed, Kirstyrsquos parents, Sharon and Gary, have no doubt their fourth child would not be with them today at their Murlough Court home, off the main Castlewellan Road.Cradling the latest addition to the family in their arms, the doting parents issued an appeal to senior officials at the Department of Health not to close the baby unit in Downpatrick.Sharon, who was due to have her baby at the Royal Maternity in Belfast, went into labour just after am on May  and with no time to go to the Royal, her husband opted to drive her to Downpatrick.ldquoAs we made our way to the hospital, Sharon was holding on and screaming with pain, her husband recalled.ldquoJust outside Newcastle we saw an ambulance parked and stopped to seethe paramedics could help, but they were already with another patient and suggested they all for help, but I decided it would be quicker to keep driving to Downpatrick.ldquoSharon was still in tremendous pain and I prayed something would happen. My prayers were answered when we met a second ambulance which I managed to stop.Gary explained that as the paramedics attended to his we, the babyrsquos head had already appeared but the umbilical chord was wrapped around tiny Kirstyrsquos neck.ldquoI helped the paramedic move it before Kirsty was delivered at the side of the road, he said. ldquoShe was placed in the ambulance and taken to the maternity unit where staff cut the umbilical chord before working to keep Kirsty alive.ldquoOur daughter is living proof of the need to ensure maternity services are retained in Downpatrick.DOWNPATRICK mdash Members of a Loyalist flute band, who plan to hold a parade in Downpatrick at the end of the month, have been urged to move the event away from the county town.The call has been issued by the residentsrsquo group, the Down Peace Forum, which has warned thatthe Red Hand Defenders fails to switch its event in just over two weeksrsquo time, it will stage a rally against what it calls a ldquosectarian parade.Members of the Loyalist band had notied the Parades Commission of their plan to hold a parade on June  and have indicated  other bands have been invited to take part.A spokesperson for the Down Peace Forum said that after consulting with its members and voluntary and community groups in the Downpatrick and surrounding area, a decision has been taken to hold a counter rally.KILLYLEAGH mdash A Killyleagh woman has been named Northern Irelandrsquos best neighbour.Anne Montgomery, who recently won the province-wide heat of the Kleeneze sponsored competition now goes forward to the national finals.Anne has already bagged pound worth of Kleeneze vouchers and a unique commemorative plaque, but is now in the running for a holiday of a letime.She was nominated for the award by her neighbour Kim Neill, who recently had a baby and was struggling to stay on top of things.She recalls: ldquoAnne was a tower of strength and helped out by lending a pram, highchair and blankets. She also offered a shoulder to cry on and would go to the shops whenever I needed groceries.BALLYHORNAN ndash Portaferry leboat was launched on Monday evening to rescue a teenager who was stranded on a boat off the Ballyhornan coastline.The  year-old boy was on a boat which was moored  feet offshore when the inshore leboat was launched.The boy, who suffered no injuries during the incident, was rescued and brought ashore at Ballyhornan, where he was reunited with an  year-old boy who had made it to shore from the boat himself.Members of the Ardglass Coastguard unit were also called to assist with the operation.STRANGFORD mdash Water Service representatives have moved quickly to quell concerns about the future of one of Strangfordrsquos best loved landmarks.A Victorian water pump at Quay Lane has been an integral part of the villagersquos back for many years, but Strangfordrsquos residents received a shock last week when it was whisked away.The pump was removed by representatives from the Water Service amid cries of protest from residents.But the government body has moved quickly to stamp out concerns about the pumprsquos future, confirming that it has simply been removed for essential repairs.The pump, which served as an artesian well prior to mains water being pumped to the village in the s, had been leaking for a period of time.ldquoOwnership of the pump is unclear, a representative from the Water Service admitted. ldquoBut we have taken it away to repair a leak in the pipe work. We are hoping to replace the pump.DUNDRUM mdash One graceful creature has flown smoothly into Keel Point outside Dundrum to cause an unlikely ripple.Birdwatchers, tourists and residents alike are in a flap over what have proved to be one of the arearsquos most unusual examples of wildle yet mdash a black swan.The dusky bird has joined a flock of classic white swans just outside the coastal village, and while it appears to have unselfconsciously blended into its fold, the black beauty is continuing to ruffle the feathers of wildle enthusiasts.The swan, an Australian native, is one of a few which are privately owned throughout the UK and wildle experts believe it has escaped captivity.KILLOUGH mdash The history and le of Killough is the subject of a new book to be launched tomorrow in the village by A former resident, Senator Maurice Hayes.lsquoKillough ndash The Church on the Loughrsquo brings together essays on the village history and collected stories by vice-principal of Ballykinlar Primary School, Christine Walsh, retired school matron Margaret Manley, archaeology lecturer Finbar McCormick and retired engineer and maritime historian Harry Madill.Published by the Palatine Trust, the book is ided into three sections and delves back over the last  years to provide some revolutionary reading on the picturesque port and fishing village.PORTAFERRY mdash The world-renowned Galway Hookers are set to sail back to Portaferry this month. The Hooker festival will combine sailing, music and dancing along Portaferryrsquos shoreline.The sailing programme will include a mini regretta, which will provide a flavour of what is to follow with the main regatta on Sunday.Bluegrass, traditional Irish, Ulster Scots, Tex Mex and Latino rhythms will drt over the shore throughout the three-day celebration of sailing. Children will also be kept entertained with several workshops planned including an introduction to kite making.ldquoAs always, the Galway Hookers are the main attraction and the backbone of the event, but you do not have to be a sailing enthusiast to make the most of the festival,rsquorsquo promised Ards Borough Councilrsquos community relations officer Paul Killen.SAINTFIELD mdash Over  people flocked to Rowallane Gardens on Sunday to participate in a special recording of Songs of Praise to celebrate Saintfieldrsquos millennium week.Sunday was very much a community affair and was the culmination of months of hard work and preparation by clergymen and helpers from the local churches.Representatives from the First and Second Presbyterian churches, Church of Ireland and the Roman Catholic Church worked together for the event, which kick-started this weekrsquos celebrations..prettyPhoto

title: Health minister hails Ryan’s act of kindness for frontline workers
story: HEALTH minister Robin Swann has put pen to paper to praise the efforts of the enterprising young Teconnaught man behind Ryanrsquos Cookie Box.Ryan Bogues mdash who lives on the Drumnaconagher Road mdash is a renowned baker who raises money for charity with his culinary delights.During the coronavirus lockdown, Ryan has been busy baking a range of tempting delights for healthcare staff and other frontline workers, with his efforts recognised by the man at the helm of the Department of Health.In his letter to Ryan, Mr Swann said that he was recently made aware of Ryanrsquos Cookie Box and the  year-oldrsquos efforts to reward as many frontline staff as he possibly could.The health minister said Ryan, who has Downrsquos Syndrome, had mixed, baked, dressed, iced, created and delivered literally thousands of buns to a range of frontline staff including nurses, care workers and even hardworking officials behind the scenes at Stormont.ldquoI would like to personally thank you for your incredible act of kindness and wish you the best for your future endeavours, added Mr Swann.The young baker and his family are delighted that in the midst of an incredible workload and the pressures of public expectations, the health minister found the time and energy to send his message of thanks.A spokesperson for the Bogues family confirmed that Ryan had received a letter from Mr Swann.ldquoItrsquos a letter of thanks to Ryan for baking the Not All Superheroes Wear Capes Thank You Hampers and itrsquos lovely, the spokesperson continued.ldquoMr Swann, it has to be said, already has a great name, but the baker boy reckons that lsquobirdmanrsquo suits him better. In fact, he is quite emphatic about it.ldquoSo to the birdman on the hill, thank you so much for taking the time to write to Ryan and also for leading one of the toughest government jobs that there is at the moment with such tireless and measured determination.Before this yearrsquos public health pandemic, Ryanrsquos baking had been raising around pound, every month for charities.And he loves his days in the family kitchen baking scones, buns and his famous lsquoendorphin barsrsquo mdash which are placed in an honesty box at the end of the driveway..prettyPhoto

title: July 31 date for return of GAA action in Down
story: DOWN County Board members were meeting last night to put their seal of approval on a plan for theof Gaelic games in the county.Board members were expected to approve the roadmap which has been put together by the powerful Down Competitions Control Committee.Under the plan, club games in the county will resume on July  with the opening round of the Senior Football League.The formats of the adult football championships will be similar to those in recent years.The first round of the Senior Football Championship will take place over August -, with the final scheduled for September .There will be a back door system for teams beaten in early rounds, but there will be no replays, except for the final,necessary.The Intermediate and Junior Football Championships also begin over August -.The Junior final is scheduled for September  and the Intermediate final on September . The winners will be promoted to a higher grade championship in . Again there will be no replays, except for the finals,necessary.There will be a change to the format of the adult senior football leagues.Each of the four isions will be ided into two sections. This will ensure that all teams will be guaranteed a minimum of four of five games.The teams finishing top in each section will compete in their respective league finals. There will be no promotion or relegation.On the senior hurling front there will be no Down League.It is proposed that the Senior Hurling Championship will be played on a round-robin basis with two rounds, home and away, and the top two teams qualying for the final.No Intermediate or Junior Hurling Championships have been arranged to date. However, provision has been made for underage football and hurling competitions..prettyPhoto

title: Last chance saloon for vandalised toilet block
story: A SECURITY camera may be used to police Saintfieldrsquos only public toilet block when it is repaired for what local council officials insist will be the final time.The toilets at the New Line mdash close to a childrenrsquos play area in the town mdash have been vandalised on numerous occasions over the years.Currently closed, Rowallane councillors have persuaded Newry, Mourne and Down Council to repair the toilets with a warning issued thatthe vandals strike again, the toilets will be closed for good, with the facility potentially removed.Council officials are currently examining the cost of repairing the toilets.The vandalism issue was raised at a recent meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnershipwhen it was revealed that bids are being made locally for finance to secure a CCTV camera for this part of Saintfield.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker made specic reference to the vandalism at the Saintfield toilets during the PCSP meeting, with police supportive of moves to secure CCTV. In addition, an undertaking was given to deploy additional police patrols to this part of Saintfield.Local politicians are also keen for anyone who knows anything about repeated vandal attacks at the toilet block to contact police.Last week, Rowallane councillors Kathryn Owen and Robert Burgess welcomed news that the toilets were to be repaired and issued an appeal for an end to the vandal attacks.Cllr Owen described the local authority commitment to repair the toilets as ldquoexcellent news and said she was pleased that agreement to carry out the work was being supported by all five Rowallane councillors.She confirmed that the local authorityrsquos assistant director for Neighbourhood Services has agreed to get costings for the required repair work and suggested thatthe repaired facility is left alone, it could pave the way for the provision of a new facility in the future.Cllr Burgess said the New Line toilet block had been targeted on many occasions over the years, explaining that every time that it was repaired it was subsequently vandalised, with ratepayers picking up the bill.He added: ldquoThe New Line toilets have been closed for some time and were included in a local authority review of public conveniences across the district to decide which facilities would be upgraded and which would not.ldquoI believe that a town the size of Saintfield requires a modern toilet facility and hope that this can happen at some point in the future. One of the most worrying aspects of previous vandalism was that a disabled cubicle was regularly targeted..prettyPhoto

title: Making a big splash
story: LECALE Swimming Club is an amateur club based at Down Leisure Centre in Downpatrick and trains over  swimmers from the age of six through to senior level.The coaching team utilises a structured swim training plan for all groups and squads, which are set up withcareful strategic analysis of performance.Teams compete in the Provisional Towns League and at a younger level in the Forestfeast Aquasprints League. Inidual swimmers also compete at internal club galas and at Swim Ulster and Swim Ireland events.Like so many sports clubs, Lecalersquos season has been cut short and the Club is missing its strong camaraderie, training and competition.Lecale coaches, committee and parents are very proud of all swimmers, and this article, in place of the clubrsquos annual awards ceremony, is a reflection of the   season.The Forest Feast Aquasprint League aims to introduce Lecalersquos young swimmers to the competitive aspect of swimming.Before lockdown, their season had just started and Lecalersquos team were delighted to host the first Aquasprint Gala of the season against City of Belfast in Down Leisure Centre. The team, captained by Harry Manley and Matilda Harty, secured a superb win.This yearrsquos Provincial Towns League galas provided a fantastic opportunity for club members to swim competitively and aim for personal best times, whilst having fun and making new friends with other clubs.The galas included a medley relay, inidual back, breast, fly and free swims, inidual medley and finally a freestyle relay for each of the four age groups.Lecalersquos galas took place from September to February with two at Down Leisure Centre and two away. Lecale swam against Cookstown, Leander, Coleraine and Portadown with some extremely close scores. Many parents, coaches and volunteers helped time and again, and this was truly appreciated.Swimmers at Lecale are able to start on the competitive pathway through development and open galas. Thirty-one swimmers have competed this season, gaining personal best times and medals.Of particular note, Tom Williamson was a medal winner in every event he entered across the four development meets of the season, winning eight gold medals, three silvers and one bronze medal.Orla Gibney shone at the Ards Christmas meet, winning two golds, a silver and a trophy for the best performance in the age  category, while Matilda Harty was in fine form at the Templemore open meet, winning medals in all four of her events mdash one gold, two silvers and a bronze.This season Lecale also had a squad of six elite swimmers who are involved in Swim Ulster Regional Talent Development and Performance Pathway, training and competing at national level.They qualied to compete in Swim Ulster meets and were placed within the top five in their age group in the spring qualying meets.Swim Ulster National Qualying Division  times were recorded for Adam Colgan, Adam Mahon and Aidan Mallett, Division  times for Christopher Mason and Rebecca Colgan and Aoe Mason were close to Division  times as the season was interrupted.Adam Colgan, Adam Mahon and Aidan Mallett qualied for the Swim Ulster short course championships in November and Aidan and Adam Colgan qualied for the McCullagh international meet in February, competing with the best swimmers in Ireland and GB, including Olympic swimmers Adam Peaty and Duncan Scott.Adam Colgan also qualied for the Irish long course meet, which serves as the Irish Olympic trials, prior to its Covid- cancellation.In challenging times for athletes used to training five or six times a week, swimmers now take part in al land work training up to three times per week under the direction of club coaches.Up to  swimmers are regularly taking part in what has become a highlight of the week. Although it cannot take the place of training in water, coaches hope power, balance and coordination levels can be maintained and that the swimmers will be to get back to business in the pool at a future date.It is always sad to say goodbye to swimmers who are ready to move on after finishing their school career. This season, Lecale said goodbye to Year  swimmers Chloe Galloway, Sarah Colgan, Peter Murphy and Tom Rodgers.Coaches, committee and club members thank them for their long and dedicated association with the club and look forward to hearing about their successes in the future.The club also wishes to thank the outgoing captains, Chloe Galloway and James Kane, for their dedication and service to the club this season.Lecale Swimming Club continues to take their lead from the governing bodies, Swim Ireland and Swim Ulster, and look forwards to welcoming swimmers back to training before too long and new members when the next season starts..prettyPhoto

title: Mr Joseph McMcIlmail
story: MR Joseph McIlmail, of Crew Road, Downpatrick, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, April , at the age of .Joe, as he was known to his family and many friends, was the fourth child of the late John Joe and Margaret McIlmail, from Bright. He was a loving brother to Margaret , Eileen , Jimmy, Mary and the late John.At the age of  he left school and started his apprenticeship as a carpenter joiner at Ballykinlar Camp for Sintons. After serving his time, he went to work in England in the early s, ing for a period when he met his we Sylvia, who he married in .The couple moved to Coventry where Joe continued to work for a few years. They ed to Downpatrick where Joe worked for several well-known local building firms, including Casements, Hugh J OrsquoBoyle and Taggarts, before he commenced his own building firm. Joe was a perfectionist with a great eye for detail and took pride in all the work he undertook.Joe had several hobbies. He loved photography and never went anywhere without a camera to capture the moment. He took the official photographs for several weddings, but ever the perfectionist he always worried how they would turn out until they were developed mdash unlike in todayrsquos digital age.Many of his interests were connected to the sea and the coast. He enjoyed fishing and always owned a small boat to go on short fishing trips. He also loved joining friends from Strangford and Kilclief on trips to the Isle of Man.Sailing was another great passion, being a crew member on trips to the Scottish and Irish coast before getting his own yacht on which he and his we were the only crew.Joe loved being in company and valued friendship. He liked meeting up with friends and family and hearing as well as telling a good story. He often couldnrsquot finish his stories from laughing too much at the memory of what he was going to tell and his laughter was infectious.He is survived by Sylvia, sons Joe, Paul and Mark, daughters Margaret and Anne, grandsons Austin, Malachy, Joseph, Eoin, Brian and Jack, granddaughters Natasha and Aimee, great grandsons Callum and John, great granddaughters Scarlett-Grace, Amelia-Rose, Lily and Eva, the wider family circle, friends and neighbours. May he rest in peace..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle woman’s new post
story: NEWCASTLE woman Fiona Hanna has been appointed as a director of the Jago communications and public relations firm.The appointment follows on from Fiona being shortlisted in the Young Communications Professional of the Year in Irelandrsquos Public Relations Awards for Excellence, coordinated by PRII and PRCA and sponsored by Kantar Media.The  year-old joined Jago in  and has progressed her career by delivering impactful campaigns for clients and developing the practice, including leading the opening of Jagorsquos Dublin office in late .As part of her directorship, Fiona will continue to develop Jagorsquos operations across Ireland..prettyPhoto

title: Open for business
story: TRADERS throughout the district are back in business after being closed during the coronavirus lockdown.Business owners in towns and villages welcomed the relaxation in opening of non-essential shops after  weeks of closure.But they sounded a cautious note of optimism about what trading for the rest of the year would mean to their continued success.Shops such as clothes retailers, hardware stores, and small department stores were only allowed to open since last Friday.It emerged at a virtual meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Active and Healthy Communities that  retailers in the district were instructed to close by council officers after they opened ahead of the allowed date. However, no fines were enforced by the council.Most towns still have shops that have not yet reopened for a iety of reasons.Shop owners need to ensure that social distancing guidelines can be adhered to and provide signposting, sanitisation sites as well as protective perspex shields at cash registers.Some of Downpatrickrsquos Market Street traders reported that while business was brisk for some days since reopening, sales were down compared to normal business levels.Liam Smyth, owner of gents and boys outfitters Minders in Market Street, said he was ldquopleasantly surprised by the level of sales the shop achieved on reopening.ldquoIt was lovely to see some of our old customers as well as some new customers and it seemed that they were just happy to get out of their homes to see what was happening and to walk around the shops, said Mr Smyth.ldquoBusiness is not back to normal as the work in St Patrickrsquos Avenue at this time is disappointing but there definitely has been a feel-good factor about.Siobhan King owns Pricewise and is marking her th anniversary of business next month.She said: ldquoSince we opened last Friday there has been a lot of positive comments from our customers and they have told us that they have been lost without us, which has been lovely.ldquoWe had a good day on Friday and Saturday but today [Monday] has been very quiet so I do wonderitrsquos going to go back to the way it was. We really need to see how the next few months go to determine the impact on the rest of the year.ldquoJune, July and August are the three months that I need to do well as I have a lot of summer stock in so itrsquos too early to say and I also rely on my unorm trade to do well.New business owner Shelly Cochrane was about to open her gt and homeware shop Dilly Dally when the closure was announced.ldquoIrsquom so relieved to finally be able to open, she said. ldquoMy shop has been very well received and people are delighted to finally be able to get out and browse and see items. Itrsquos such a relief to be able to trade, to be able to lt some money instead of having to pay it out as I had already stock bought.Nuala Maguire manages Houstonrsquos in Downpatrick and reported that early trading has proved positive.ldquoThe first few days were very good and our customers told us how glad they were to see us open, she said.ldquoWe had been very busy but today [Monday] has probably been our slowest day since we opened. But overall, itrsquos been very encouraging.In Newcastle, Fred Wadsworth, owner of Wadsworthrsquos, the long established department store, reported that business was ldquojust OK at the moment.Mr Wadsworth said: ldquoItrsquos nowhere what we would normally be doing, but itrsquos ticking over. I do think that some of our customers are still concerned about ing to shopping and it will take a while for things to settle and to get back back to the norm again.ldquoThe town has certainly come back to le mdashNewcastle is ready and willing to welcome shoppers back.Scott Kidd, manager of Irelandrsquos Appliance Centre in the resort, praised customers for their patience in getting used to the lsquonew normalrsquo way of shopping.He said: ldquoIn general, shoppers have been very good since we reopened.Initially when we reopened, business was below what we normally do but it has picked up.ldquoDuring lockdown, we were able to provide essential items such as cookers, washing machines and freezers and I believe that went down really well with our local shoppers.ldquoBut I believe that shops like ours should have been allowed to remain open.The re-opening for the majority of traders in Downpatrick and surrounding towns went ahead of the Stormont Executive confirming that hotels, bars, restaurants and cafes could reopen from July .Former chairperson of Newry, Newry and Down Council, Mark Murnin is an owner of the popular Ballynahinch bar, Paddy Kellyrsquos. He also remains chairperson of Ballynahinch Chamber of Commerce.He reported that while most of the shops in Ballynahinch had reopened and normality had resumed, there as still several traders who had not opened on Monday.ldquoMost of the shops have opened and there is definitely business going on, but itrsquos not quite back to the same level, said Mr Murnin.While hewelcomed the earlier reopening of bars and other licensed premises, he warned customers that it would not be exactly the same experience.ldquoDrinking will be an outdoor experience as customers will only be insidethey are eating. There will be no televisions, etc and people will not be able to drink for the same amount of time, he said.ldquoIrsquom concerned that we are opening too soon and how itrsquos going to work. We closed before we were told as we had dficulty in getting people to social distance.ldquoI would like to see some protection for us in how we look after our customers and they are given a very clear message to behave when they are out..prettyPhoto

title: Public toilets reopen after lockdown easing
story: RESTRICTIONS on spending a penny across the district due to the coronavirus pandemic have been signicantly eased this week.The Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs and Newry, Mourne and Down Council have reopened a number of public toilets to address the needs of locals and visitors flushed with frustration at not being able to use the loos for the past few months.Public toilets at Castlewellan and Tollymore forest parks have been reopened by the government department, while local authority-owned toilets have reopened at the Bloody Bridge outside Newcastle and at Donard Park and the Downs Road in the resort.Council officials have also reopened toilets at the Quoile picnic area in Downpatrick and those adjacent to Ballyhornan beach. However, all facilities will close at pm.Within the next two weeks, additional council toilet facilities will reopen at three locations in Newcastle mdash Castle Park, Central Promenade and South Promenade, with council-owned toilets at Spelga Dam also set to reopen.The council says it is reopening toilet blocks between am and pm as part of a ldquophased approach balancing service provision, resources and the health and safety of the public and local authority staff.The organisation says that reopening public toilets will increase the districtrsquos tourist offering, confirming that work is underway to open additional toilet blocks on a phased basis with the hope to have as many as possible open at the height of the summer.But a warning has been issued that the reopening plan depends upon available resources to ensure that all facilities are serviced to the standard required.ldquoIt is vital to provide facilities that are maintained to a level that mitigates the risk of cross-contamination and possible transfer of Covid- among members of the public, said a council spokesman.Council officials say the measures taken to reopen public conveniences include increased frequency of cleansing and inspection, social distancing and hand washing signage and hand sanitisers provided outside each facility.In addition, the local authority says that its plan to reopen all public conveniences across the district will be continually reviewed..prettyPhoto

title: Removal of statue is ‘ridiculous’
story: CALLS for the removal of a statue in west London in honour of one of Killyleaghrsquos most famous sons have been branded ldquoridiculous by a local politician.The statue of Sir Hans Sloane is included on a list of monuments that should be removed over his perceived links to slavery.Activists from the Black Lives Matter movement want the statue in honour of Sir Hans removed, while a campaign has been launched to replace it with a tribute to former Cha footballers Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Eidur Gudjohnsen.It is Sloanersquos marriage to Elizabeth Rose mdash the daughter of a wealthy slave planter in Jamaica ndash bringing him a one-third share of the net profits from her fatherrsquos vast plantations, which has put him on the list of Black Lives Matters campaigners.In addition, campaigners want to rename streets named after Sir Hans in the highly fashionable Knightsbridge area such as Sloan Square because he derived part of his wealth from his slave owner father-in-law who owned plantations in Jamaica.The collections of Sir Hans Sloane helped found the first museum in the world - the British Museum - and he was personal physician to three dferent English monarchs. He was also famous for discovering milk chocolate.Born in Killyleagh on April , , Sir Hans died in Cha in , aged  and described as the worldrsquos greatest collector who, from his earliest years, catalogued and carefully encased every artefact that he found.Over the years he accumulated nearly , items many of which today are on display in the British Museum.Close to the picturesque harbour in Killyleagh stands a copy of the London statue in honour of Sir Hans with a local councillor branding the campaign to take down the statues in the capital as ldquoridiculousCllr Billy Walker insists that the pioneering physician was not a slave trader and that the clamour for many statues to be taken down was becoming ldquosilly, urging the Government to show some backbone on the matter.He said Sir Hans was ldquorevered in his home town where people were proud to have a copy of the statue to a man who did so much for the world.Cllr Walker continued: ldquoSir Hans gave us the concept of free museums, found a cure for smallpox and pioneered science and medicine to do away with magic for treating illness.ldquoHe also promoted the use of quinine against malaria, discovered milk chocolate and was the first man to lead both Royal Colleges. Sir Hans also treated the poor for free and was no slave trader.Cllr Walker said Sir Hans left Killyleagh for London when he was  where he studied chemistry, before deciding on a career in medicine, qualying in France and ing to London.He was subsequently appointed as the personal physician to the governor of Jamaica and it was there that he discovered drinking chocolate.When he ed to England, Sir Hans was able to market his find and Cadburyrsquos promoted this drink for many years.Cllr Walker said that Sir Hans, who has a centre named after him in his home town, encouraged inoculation against ious diseases and for  years was President of the Royal College of Surgeons and a Fellow and hard working secretary of the Royal Society for many years.ldquoWe in Killyleagh are rightly very proud of Sir Hans and his links with our town, he continued.The councillor added: ldquoI hope that his statue in London will remain in place as he was a man of great distinction which is evidenced by the fact that there is now a centre dedicated to him in his home town. Killyleagh is fiercely proud of Sir Hans and his achievements..prettyPhoto

title: Restoration of emergency services at Downe must be top priority
story: THERE is substantial disquiet within our community concerning the future of the emergency department at Downe Hospital.The time is now long overdue for the South Eastern Trust to confirm that its intention is to restore our emergency department service to its pre-Covid- level and to provide a firm indication of the date on which it believes that that will happen.Clearly, that date cannot be far into the future.Downe Hospital has played a crucial role in the emergency response to the Covid- pandemic. In addition to the services directly provided at our local hospital mdash the peoplersquos hospital mdash Downe staff were redeployed to other healthcare facilities andcontributed enormously to the NHS effort.When the emergency planning was taking effect, it was the clear understanding of many local political and community representatives, that the emergency department service would be restored immediately upon the conclusion of the pandemic.Whilst there is clearly a signicant possibility of a so-called second surge in infections mdash and we are all aware as to just how serious such a second surge could be mdash at the same time there is increased normalisation of health provision across the North.The restoration of the urgent care service previously provided at the Downe must be a top priority as part of this normalisation. It should have been included in the June action plan, published by the health trust last week.Just last week, as attendances were increasing at the remaining emergency departments, including at the Ulster Hospital, it was apparent that existing facilities are and will be unable to cope with demand.During the Covid emergency planning, decisions were taken to temporarily close the emergency departments at the Downe, Daisy Hill and the Mater hospitals.Just last week, trade union representatives received categorical assurances from the Southern Trust about the re-opening of about Daisy Hill Hospital. Similar assurances are now required about the Downe.There is also a signicant impetus gathering now for the implementation of restructuring of healthcare services generally, and of urgent care in particular, across Northern Ireland.Decisions about the future of healthcare, particularly urgent care, afford an excellent opportunity to redress health inequalities that have arisen and been perpetuated by the historic under investment in the health service by successive governments and by the pursuit of centralisation policies.Many people believe that those centralisation policies played a crucial role in leaving us facing into a pandemic with insufficient hospital beds, insufficient intensive care beds, insufficient ambulance cover, insufficient ventilators and insufficient healthcare workers.Any change to emergency and urgent care provision is only permissible where it happens with the consent of the people.In the final analysis, decisions about the allocation of healthcare resources are political decisions taken by politicians, elected by the people and not by bureaucrats. Tiers and levels of bureaucracy make no dference to where ultimate responsibility lies.I have a great deal of sympathy for the recently appointed health minister, Robin Swann, who within a few weeks of his appointment, found himself facing the biggest public health emergency in the history of the National Health Service.I would respectfully suggest that Mr Swann should insist upon the criteria for change stated by Michelle OrsquoNeill when she was Health Minister.The now Deputy First Minister stated in November  that local people should be at the centre of decision-making processes in designing and delivering services. The , people who marched through Downpatrick in support of the Downe Hospitalin the Love the Downe Rally on February , , would certainly agree with that.As far back as , Dr Michael McBride, speaking at the sod cutting ceremony for the new Downe Hospital, said that ldquothe emphasis would be on making the health system respond to the patient rather than the patient to the system. I concur with that.In the Down Recorder of November , , after the publication of the Bengoa Report, Michelle OrsquoNeill was quoted as saying: ldquoWe will deliver care and support in the most appropriate settings, ideally in peoplersquos homes and communities.Again, I would concur with that.If there is to be a change in urgent care provision across Northern Ireland, no one can expect to be immune from that change. At the same time, change would only be possible or acceptableit is to create a better service for all of the people and a fair and equitable distribution of services.Many people in this area believe that we have had a very raw deal for over  years from the health service and some politicians.It sometimes seems to be forgotten that the National Health Service is free at the point of use, but it is certainly not without cost. It is the people who pay for it.Rural communities have particular characteristics and needs that must be addressed, in terms of at the most basic, accessibility to services. Like everyone , they have rights.Access to healthcare is a right, not a privilege.If it is to be the case that urgent care is being restructured, citizens in rural areas which, for this purpose, includes virtually anyone outside the Greater Belfast area, cannot be expected to forego services so that Belfast can continue to enjoy a proleration of emergency services, with not one but two Type  emergency departments on the scale of that at the Ulster Hospital, on its overdeveloped and cramped site, the Royal Victoria Hospital and the Mater, with the Type  unit at the Lagan Valley hospital, just seven miles from Belfast, a similar distance to that travelled by the people of Ardglass to the Downe hospital.Of course, Type  emergency departments are also to be found at Antrim and Craigavon, neither of which are far from Belfast and are linked by the best possible road infrastructure.Logically, it would seem, that the existence of two Type  units in Belfast is not sustainable, given the apparent massive pressure on services.We were told by the Department of Health at the time of the January  public meeting in Downpatrick Cricket Club that the purpose of that meeting was to enable local people to ldquofundamentally shape, inform and influence the criteria to be used to deliver services in the future.We hope that is still the case and await meaningful engagement with the community before change is implemented.The then deputy permanent secretary was quoted as having said that the then Minister would want to see ldquoongoing engagement in redesigning services. I am sure that the current Health Minister has the same views.The challenge for the Health Minister in the future must surely be to develop a fair and equitable distribution of services that would end discrimination against rural communities and ensure that all services, including ambulance services, are readily accessible to all of the people.It is worth remembering as well, that there was actually a .%in the attendances at emergency departments in Northern Ireland between December  and December . In the same period, attendances at the Downe Hospitalrsquos emergency department rose signicantly.Decisions about change in the health service are political decisions. All of the major parties form the Northern Ireland Executive, which is collectively accountable for the program for government and all that it delivers or fails to deliver for the people.It is imperative that any attempt to change or restructure healthcare provision in Northern Ireland is done so in full consultation with the end users of the services, who are also the paymasters for it. This will be very dficult, as history has created a deep mistrust between substantial elements in our community and the Department of Health.Our community has suffered greatly from repeated cuts to services and the ruthless pursuit of a centralisation agenda a pursuit that has continued even in recent years when the NHS in England and Wales has been investing in and supporting smaller hospitals, recognising their crucial roles at the heart of local communities and using technological advances to support them.If it appears that Covid- is being used as a cover to implement long-standing Department of Health policy, then any changes would be resented by the community and in fact rejected by it. This would lead to an irreparable breach of trust between the people and the State.If an attempt is made to in any way reduce the services that are currently on offer at the Downe Hospital, this community, as it has done before, will rise up in righteous indignation.Twenty five thousand people took to the streets of Downpatrick in February . If our emergency department is not restored within a reasonable timescale mdash a matter of weeks mdash it is very likely that this area will see an unprecedented display of anger, with , plus people on the street, with legal challenges about any perceived abuse of process and a community-wide campaign, a cross-community campaign and political upheaval at the highest level of government.The people of East and South Down have had enough. They have reluctantly sacriced local services, as a temporary measure in the short term, but their resolve should not be underestimated.The people of Newcastle, Ballynahinch, Castlewellan, Ardglass, Killough, Clough, Downpatrick, Strangford, Crossgar, Lower Mourne and the vast surrounding rural hinterland need these services.Farmers, fishermen and builders need emergency care as much as ever, so too do the tourists who flock into our area every year and probably will do so in even greater numbers this year.It is time to restore the Downe Hospitalrsquos emergency department and it is time to concentrate investment in local services, delivering for the people who need the services, where they need those services.The NHS must serve the people from ldquocradle to grave. It is a part of the social contract between the people and those who govern them.Politicians and administrators come and go. The Downe hospital must live on, developing all the time the range of services it offers.Equality demands nothing less..prettyPhoto

title: Revered servant of local cricket
story: Robin Walsh remembers Alfie Linehan, the distinguished Downpatrick cricket stalwart who died last yearTHE great paradox of Alfie Linehan was to be found in his disposition on the cricket field and off it.At the crease, his was a belligerent style, hitting the ball farther than anyone , compiling his runs in a manner that kept the scorers busy. Beyond the boundary!Yet this domineering, almost bullying, approach belied one of Irish cricketrsquos truest gentlemen off it: soft-spoken, never a word that offended, never a word against him.In one of the most distinguished legacies to the local game, the late Downpatrick farmer captained the Ireland team before turning to administration in the roles of chairman and president of the Northern Cricket Union and president of the Irish Cricket Union.Yet it was where it mattered most, at the grassroots of the game, that Alfie left his indelible mark.His devotion to the Downpatrick club and its famous international ground The Meadow was boundless and le-long, from underage player to captain of the club, coach and ultimately chairman and president.He either played or captained Downpatrick in five NCU Senior League, three Senior Cup-winning sides and an Irish Senior Cup triumph along with his older brother Hugh, another talented batsman whose death at the age of  dealt a terrible blow to Alfie.In later years it was a source of great pride that Hughrsquos son, Paul, was to captain the club and daughter Anne played for Ireland.His wersquos nephew, James Cunningham, also captained the club.Alfiersquos hard-hitting ways over four decades from the s took him to  Irish appearances mdash six of them as captain mdash in the days when international caps were much less liberally awarded, and his contribution to the success of NCU representative cricket has rarely been equalled.Administration was an endless labour of love at local, provincial and national level. Such was his accommodating nature that he chaired countless committees ranging from solving an umpire shortage in the NCU to raising funds at ICU golf days.His contribution to his local community extended far beyond the boundaries of the cricket club.In his day he was a member of the NI Sports Council, a director of his local hospital trust and president of Ardglass Golf Club.Alfiersquos friends were legion, none more close than Cecil Walker, that leading light of the Lisburn club.Their playing days over, they travelled the world with their wives watching international cricket and storing delightful memories of new friendships, whether tales of the Bodyline era over tea with Harold Larwood at his home in Sydney, or a fond mention by David lsquoBumblersquo Lloyd from the commentary box.Of all thatrsquos been written down the years about Alfie Linehan, one game has been overlooked and yet it speaks more than any of his commitment to Downpatrick.It was Saturday, August , , and Downpatrick were due to play Lurgan. It was also the day of Alfiersquos wedding to his beloved Mary. No problem: wedding in the morning, cricket in the afternoon, reception in the evening, off on honeymoon the next day.Of all the tributes paid to Alfie none has been more signicant than that on BBC Televisionrsquos Sports Personality of the Year programme last December.He was included in the prestigious roll of honour of international sports personalities who had died during . The programme called them ldquospecial people.My own personal memory of Alfie will always be the toast he iniably delivered at the end of an eveningrsquos conviviality, of which there were many:ldquoMay you always walk in sunshineSlumber warm when night winds blowMay you always live with laughterFor a smile becomes you soThis article was first published on the CricketEurope website as part of a series paying tribute to those who have made signicant contributions to Irish cricket..prettyPhoto

title: Traffic calming measures are needed at Castlewellan road
story: TWO local Sinn Fein representatives have voiced their concern over speeding traffic on a Castlewellan road.MLA Emma Rogan and Cllr Roacuteisiacuten Howell say residents in the Burrenwood Road area have contacted them over the speed of some of the vehicles.However, they are both disappointed with the responsive their queries received from the Department of Infrastructure.Cllr Howell said that while the road met the criteria for traffic calming measures to be introduced and had been earmarked as a priority, the Department was unable to carry out the work at present.She remarked: ldquoWhile both myself and the local community welcome that Burrenwood Road has been recognised as a priority, it is extremely frustrating that due to an oversubscribed waiting list the work will not be carried out.ldquoItrsquos very annoying for us to hear the road now meets criteria but wonrsquot be completed due to it not sitting high enough on a waiting list.Cllr Howell added: ldquoThis is a disappointing response and I understand the frustration of residents.Ms Rogan said she would be contacting the Infrastructure minister to ascertain when the work will be carried out.She added: ldquoThe safety of pedestrians especially young children must be paramount..prettyPhoto

title: Virtual meeting to support businesses affected by virus
story: PLANS have been unveiled for a virtual meeting to help businesses across the district which have been severely hit by the coronavirus pandemic.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Downpatrick councillor John Trainor are organising a so-called lsquotown hallrsquo event designed to offer solutions for business operations post Covid-.The event mdash which takes place next Wednesday evening on Zoom at pm ndash will feature expert advice from a number of leading figures from the business world.They include Glyn Roberts of Retail Northern Ireland and Colin Neill of Hospitality NI, who will be joined by Tourism NIrsquos chief executive, John McGrillen.Mr McGrath and Cllr Trainor want as many businesses as possible to join the June  video conference event and ask the questions that matter to them.The Assemblyman believes that itrsquos incumbent on politicians, Northern Ireland Executive ministers and MPs to fight for businesses and help develop strategies that will benefit them post-coronavirus.ldquoNext weekrsquos virtual meeting is deigned to provide these businesses with key advice so that when they all reopen, they will continue providing the first class service they have been offering, in some instances, for decades, said Mr McGrath.ldquoI have been working with our local council SDLP team in establishing a video conference call with expert figures from this sector.Mr McGrath said next weekrsquos event will outline his partyrsquos plans for how it will work with local business as everyone prepares to exit lockdown.He added: ldquoI would encourage as many businesses as possible to get in touch and wersquoll get you connected with this quickly evolving network of local business support and advice.Cllr Trainor said while the financial support offered by the NI Executive to many businesses to help them cope with the challenges of coronavirus was welcome, his party was keen to explore what would happen post Covid- and what support would be required.He added: As a result of the initial shock and upheaval caused by the pandemic, businesses have lost a great deal and some have had to shut up shop entirely.ldquoThere is much fear and concern over what will happen to the businesses that are still operating, in particular, those in the retail, hospitality and tourism sectors..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. Phil, who used to wear XL shirts and had a waistline of  inches, was recently ill with what was thought to be Covid-. He believes that while it was unpleasant and he was knocked off his feet, he’s not sure he would have survivedhe hadn’t lost weight. He said: “I dread to think how my body would have responded. It was a timely reminder of how important my health is.”Phil Kayes before shedding  stones " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...At his heaviest Phil suffered a string of other health issues including pressure on his knees and sleep apnoea. His main worry was that would he die in his sleep and his body couldn’t be removed from the third floor of his parents’ house.Phil, who has slimmed from st .lbs to st lbs in three years, said: “I was always bigger than my peers – I remember at school being called out by my PE teacher for being too big to play football. “The weight really started to pile on though when I started university. My size meant my le became increasingly insular and I made up a iety of excuses not to go out.“I’d avoid gatherings like parties and weddings because I just felt so uncomfortable. I knew I wouldn’t fit into a plane seat so I never travelled, even though I really wanted to. Apart from my job as a civil servant, I didn’t really do anything except hide away and eat. It was a very lonely time.”Phil Kayes with his partner Nicole MullhollandPhil realised he had to do something about his weight when his mother was diagnosed with terminal cancer: “Mum was facing her fourth cancer battle which sadly turned out to be her last.
